name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 14 September 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear colleagues, unfortunately once again at the opening of our works we are forced to remember innocent victims of international terrorism, according to what is now becoming a very sad custom for us. This time the killing spree has hit two women. It is evident that this doubly vile choice is by no means accidental. The equal dignity between men and women achieved with difficulty by our European civilization is among the values ​​to which we are most attached and is one of the elements that most characterizes our way of living and thinking. By hitting women, you want to hit what is most important to us. On behalf of Parliament I want to express our closeness to the families of these two innocent women murdered yesterday in Marseille, our solidarity with the people of this French and European city and our increased determination to defend the values ​​we believe in. We will not lower our heads, nor will we change the way of life and we will carry on until we have defeated terrorism. A few minutes ago, through a statement, ISIS claimed the paternity of what happened today in Las Vegas. No one will ever be able to explain what can push a person to commit such terrible acts towards other human beings. In any case, whatever its origin, because the United States government does not confirm the terrorist matrix, on behalf of the European Parliament I would like to express our solidarity and sincere condolences to all those involved in this tragic event: we are all close to the innocent victims and families who are grieving the loss of loved ones in such dramatic circumstances. I thank the emergency services who have courageously worked to help their fellow citizens. Finally, I want to remember the victims of the attack that took place last Saturday, in Edmonton, Canada. I would be grateful if you could join me in observing a minute of silence in memory of all these innocent people.(Parliament stands, observes a minute of silence)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents on 28 October under Rule 149, was distributed.The following proposed amendments were tabled: Monday No amendments proposed Tuesday The Europe of Nations and Freedom Group requested that the discussion on the state of play of the negotiations with the UK be not followed by any resolution.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I propose that the vote on the motion for a resolution on the state of play of negotiations with the UK be taken off the agenda. During negotiations the European Parliament does not – and should not – play any formal role. This is just grandstanding obstruction offering headlines for Guy Verhofstadt. The real conservatives in here understand free market principles. The groups opposite do not. Instead, I suggest that you go back to your countries and request that your Heads of State request that Michel Barnier negotiate a free trade deal with the UK. That is in your interests because, if not, your economies will suffer. That is a more constructive use of time. Otherwise we are just going to walk away, because we have 40 free trade agreements that we can sign up to the day we walk out of here. So, colleagues, do the right thing.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I disagree with the proposal because it is the role of Parliament to steer the whole process, as we have to approve the outcome of the negotiations at the end. In order to be able to do that after the negotiations, we need to act in advance, and that is what we are doing – especially because, in this resolution, we put all the emphasis on citizens’ rights. It is the role of Parliament to defend the rights of citizens, not only our European citizens but also the UK citizens living on the continent. Now is the right moment – just before the next negotiation round and before the European Council takes a position.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I received a request from the Verts / ALE group to include on Tuesday's agenda a discussion on the "Objection pursuant to Article 106: draft Commission regulation amending Annex II of Regulation (EC) no.1107/2009 establishing scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties ".

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Mr President, the issue of endocrine disruptors is one of those issues that obsess many of our fellow citizens, who fear that Europe could allow the sale of poisons that pollute what they eat, what they drinkand what they breathe.It therefore seems to me absolutely appropriate that after the very clear vote of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, we are having a debate on this matter in this chamber.We know to what extent "science" is used in a more than questionable way to justify decisions which have for primary goal to favor the interests of the companies which market these products.So I suggest that we discuss it here, before the vote.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us turn to the question of Spain and Catalonia.I have received several requests from different parliamentary groups.First of all, I would like to ask the House whether or not they agree with organizing such a debate, then ask when the debate should take place and finally decide on the title, as there are three different proposals.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we did indeed request a debate on which I would like to ask colleagues to vote. However you feel about the referendum, I think we cannot – as Europe – turn a blind eye to the police violence that we saw yesterday in Catalonia. Violence can never be used as a tool for solving political conflict. Only politics can solve political conflicts.  It is clear that we need dialogue now – that is the only way forward. Therefore, Europe needs to watch closely. We should also offer mediation in order to overcome the problem that we have. Therefore, we urge you to support our request for a debate on the police violence in Catalonia against peaceful citizens.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Ska Keller, before moving on to the title of the debate that you have illustrated in relation to the Verts / ALE group, I would like to see in the meantime whether the House is in favor of this debate.I think so, but I prefer to check with a vote: who is in favor of holding a debate on the Spain - Catalonia issue?(Parliament agrees) The debate will take place.There are several proposals regarding the date of the debate: the Verts / ALE group proposes Tuesday;the GUE / NGL and ALDE groups on Wednesday;S & amp; D and PPE groups propose Thursday.(Reactions in the Chamber).There is not much to laugh about.We are talking about a very serious issue about which there is nothing to laugh about.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- (IT) Mr President, we are simply in favor of the debate being held on Wednesday.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Does the Verts / ALE Group keep its proposal for Wednesday?(Confirmation from the Verts / ALE Group) We therefore agree to hold the debate on Wednesday.But is it okay in the morning?As the presence of the Commission will be required, it would be better to hold the debate in the morning.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, as far as we know, on Wednesday morning we have a debate on the preparation of the Council meeting. Do we change the agenda for Wednesday morning? Shall we move it somewhere? We have to decide when.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Speaking time is reduced a bit.If there is no agreement, you have to vote.The EPP and ALDE groups propose to hold the debate in the afternoon.I think there is an agreement on Wednesday afternoon.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it seems you have jumped the gun before I spoke. The eyes of the world are on the European Union here. To delay this until Wednesday would send a clear message and embarrass a certain Member State. If we go ahead and have this debate, certainly tomorrow at the very earliest, that is a reasonable request. The eyes of the world are looking to the European Union and the European Parliament to speak on this issue. I feel that the debate should take place on Tuesday.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Plenary voted, so the debate will take place on Wednesday afternoon as the first item on the agenda.Let us now move on to the title of the debate: the Verts / ALE and GUE / NGL groups have called for the Commission statement to address police violence against peaceful citizens in Catalonia.The EPP, S & amp; D and ALDE groups called for a declaration on the Constitution, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Spain in the light of the events in Catalonia.The EFDD group called for a Commission statement on the rule of law and violent hostile actions by the Spanish government against the Catalan people.The EFDD group, unlike the others, asked for the discussion to be concluded with a resolution.We start listening to the groups explaining their requests.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we requested this title because there will certainly be different views about the referendum – ‘yes’, ‘no’, whatever – but I think we can have a clear, united stance when it comes to asserting that violence is never the way to solve a political problem. Here in this case, as in every other political conflict, we need a political solution. We need dialogue. We also need to see what we can do from the European level to help to mediate and solve the problem, and, for that reason, we need to watch closely what is happening and we need to offer all the help we can give. We should ask the Commission what they intend to do, and we should ask the Commission to offer mediation. There have been calls for international mediation and that is why we think this title is the one we can unite around.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we are, of course, worried about the violent situation and the lack of dialogue in Catalonia. Nevertheless, the problem is larger than this. That is why the S&D Group is proposing the following title: this should be a debate and a Commission statement ‘on the constitution, rule of law and fundamental rights in Spain in the light of the events in Catalonia’. This is the title that my Group is proposing and it is also backed by other Groups.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, I would like to support the remarks made by Mrs Rodrigues on behalf of the Socialist Group, and say that, for our PPE Group, there are all the same fundamental principles to be respected.I would like to remind you that the European Union has never agreed to get involved in referendums that take place in a Member State, and all the more so when it comes to an unconstitutional referendum.On the other hand, what is important is to recall the fundamental principles of the Union: it is that the law must be respected and applied.This is why I support, on behalf of the PPE Group, the Socialist Group proposal put forward by Mrs Rodrigues, and we insist that it be entitled "The Constitution, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Spain tothe light of events in Catalonia ”.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group.- Mr President, I would like to support the proposal and stress that I fully agree with what Mrs Ska Keller has said, except for its conclusion.It has indeed demonstrated the need for a much broader debate.It is for this reason that the title we are proposing includes fundamental rights.Fundamental rights, that's what we'll be talking about as well, and I think the best thing is to have a title that is as broad as possible, rather than getting bogged down in a single point.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, I do not believe that any of the titles proposed are appropriate, and for an extremely simple reason, namely that each of these titles in reality prejudges the content of the debate.If you talk about violence, obviously, we are moving towards a condemnation of the Spanish state.If you are talking about the rule of law, we will assume that the rule of law has been violated.By whom was he raped?There are events happening in Catalonia.Either everyone comes to this debate with preconceived ideas, and does not intend to change them, and in that case, this debate is irrelevant.Either the debate must be, which I personally think, truly open, in which case we must open the debate on the events that have occurred in Catalonia or on the situation in Catalonia;it seems to me that is quite sufficient.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Hon.Arnott has to submit the request from the EFDD group which, I repeat, unlike the other groups, also provides for a resolution at the end of the discussion.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, to see those police actions, to see 761 injuries, to see ballot boxes being seized – that is alien to everything that we cherish if we claim to uphold democracy. These matters are questions of rule of law, they are questions of self-determination and they are also questions of the actions of the police. That is why our proposal is to include all of those elements that have been mentioned on both sides.  The important point here is not just the title of the debate, but that this does not end up being something that is brushed under the carpet. What is happening in Catalonia is something which could become an incredibly serious and major diplomatic issue in months and years to come and this is something which needs to be got right. We cannot brush this under the carpet.  One thing that I would say is that we must not forget that is important, within our motion, that we add a resolution as part of the debate. It is not just about having the debate, it is about winding it up with a resolution so that we are actually saying something.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: - Mr President, colleagues!We all know that the situation is serious and that we are very concerned about the reports from Catalonia.It is now clear that we have the debate, that we will get it too.Now it's all about the title.We have offered the Greens that we include fundamental rights in the title of the resolution.That means we tried to build bridges to the Green.I don't understand why we still have to argue about it now.Let us please take up the great consensus that we now have on the proposal of the Social Democrats.Let's just discuss things this week.I therefore ask, Mr President, that the Social Democrats' proposal be voted first.(Applause)

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the most important thing is that we have a debate. It is quite clear that there are Members of this Parliament who have something to be fearful of. Let us just remind ourselves about what we saw yesterday: it was not clashes between police and protesters. What we saw was an EU Member State using armed police to physically prevent people from exercising their right to vote. We need to ensure that the voice of this Parliament is strong and robust and that we defend the rights of the people of Catalonia and in turn defend the rights of democrats right across the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Can you tell me which proposal you support because I didn't understand it?Was your intervention in support of the proposal of the GUE / NGL group?(Mr Carthy confirms) So Mrs Zimmer's next speech will also be in support of the GUE / NGL Group's request.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: - Mister President!To make this clear: We support - since we introduced this application ourselves together with the Greens - the formulation that was put forward by Ska Keller.But we are also ready and think it makes sense to include the wording that fundamental rights must be included in the title.So to that extent we could find a common solution here.At the same time, however, I am very clearly against a resolution because I think that it would actually be interference that we should not simply break over the knee here.We should just let it go, we should come to an understanding here and send a clear signal.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I believe that I am the first Spaniard to speak, and I would like all honorable Members to be aware that the matter we are talking about is very serious and that we do not have to treat it superficially. There are not only the images of yesterday that we all would have preferred not to see. In addition, at stake is a unilateral declaration of independence against the Constitution that has been announced for next Thursday and that can break my country in two halves. That is why, with all due respect and all seriousness, I ask that we vote on the majority proposal, that we hold the debate when we have decided it and that a debate be held, if possible with the Commission, and that there is only one turn to speak. intervention by group so that the presidents speak and the debate is of the highest level. There are things in the European Union that you cannot play with. Here we are to unite. What this Parliament cannot do is help to divide and break up.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Zimmer, if I understand correctly, you are in favor of Mr Weber's proposal to have a title which also includes the aspect of rights, so can we vote on Mr Weber's request?Does the Verts / ALE group also agree?Well, I therefore seem to recognize a unanimity or an overwhelming majority of the Parliament….Is the EFDD Group opposed to this proposal?(reactions without microphone, inaudible) Calm down!We are now voting on Mr Weber's proposal, which brings together all the proposals under the title as formulated in the S & amp; D Group proposal: Constitution, rule of law and fundamental rights in Spain in the light of events in Catalonia.(Parliament approved the amendment request) Thursday No amendments proposed (The order of business was thus established)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Gabriel Mato, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down the management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Convention Area of the International Commissionfor the conservation of Atlantic tuna (ICCAT) (COM (2016) 0401 - C8-0224 / 2016 - 2016/0187 (COD)) (A8-0173 / 2017).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker. –Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the political agreement reached in the trilogues on the transposition into European Union law of the recommendations regarding the management, conservation and control measures applicable in the ICCAT convention area. I think it is essential, although, listening to some of the previous interventions, one wonders if it is really worthwhile to continue talking about Law, about laws, when some absolutely pass them, they transgress them without any problem. In any case, I am not going to elaborate much on the content, but I do want to highlight some very clear messages. First of all, of course, I want to express my thanks to the Council, the Commission and the shadow rapporteurs who have made this Agreement possible. The Agreement provides for equal conditions for all operators, both from the European Union and abroad, operating in the same area. Ensuring the same conditions for everyone in the same area where European fleets compete with foreign fleets is crucial if we are to have the trust of fishermen. Much more stringent measures are often applied in the European Union fleet than those adopted in regional fisheries management organizations. We have to convince third countries, through our action in RFMOs, to follow the rules of the European Union in these cases. For example, transshipment at sea, which is prohibited for European Union vessels in European Union waters. Transshipment at sea is one of the main causes of the lack of transparency in fishing worldwide and that facilitates IUU fishing. And this is often done by foreign fleets, always the same at the global level - and there is no need to mention them - with low social or non-environmental considerations. It is important to continue making every effort to export our sustainability standards for fleets from third countries. The final agreed text urges the European Commission to take all the necessary steps to extend the Union ban to all waters. It is something that for many years our sector has requested - and legitimately - and I think we have to be grateful. The agreed text also highlights the need to pay special attention to traditional and artisanal fishing and to offer incentives to bluefin tuna and swordfish fishermen in the European Union who use fishing gear and techniques to reduce environmental impact and that this is taken into account when the quotas are distributed at the national level. That was a battle that we had with the Member States and that we negotiated very well then for bluefin tuna, and now that commitment is confirmed. However, I am very concerned that the Commission, almost a year after ICCAT adopted a multi-year recovery plan on Mediterranean swordfish - an iconic species whose stocks are in very poor condition - has not sent Parliament European no proposal transposing this plan. And that is the general trend of the Commission: more delay than would be desirable. I am convinced that the Commissioner does not agree either and views this very negatively. In fact, we are going to adopt, we are going to transpose, a series of ICCAT measures that are now obsolete and outdated. We are talking about measures from ten years ago. These measures were put on the table ten years ago and we are going to approve these recommendations now: there is no justification. This leads to legal uncertainty for operators and legitimate criticism from interested parties. This situation is legal and, more importantly, politically unacceptable. Therefore, we have submitted a statement to the final text expressing our concerns. I know, Commissioner, that you are going to accept it willingly, and have there must be a commitment from the Commission so that these rules are not born dead. Today we approved recommendations that have already been exceeded a year ago by a plan in relation to swordfish. And I also have to acknowledge my dissatisfaction with the latest decision taken by ICCAT on setting swordfish quotas in the Mediterranean without taking into account, at the same time, that the vessels engaged in this fishery are the same as engaged in bluefin tuna fishing. And, while they reduce, surely rightly, the quotas of swordfish, they do not increase those of bluefin tuna, when it has been shown that after a very well carried out plan the population has completely and completely recovered. I simply hope that now, Commissioner, in the month of November in Marrakech, where there is a new ICCAT meeting, that recovery is clearly reflected in a very notable increase in quotas and, furthermore, in a more equitable distribution and that take into account - as I said at the beginning - small boats, artisan boats and boats that are more respectful with the environment. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you once again for the good disposition you have had at all times and think and pose the challenge - which I am sure the commissioner will accept - that the transposition of the recommendations will not take ten years: if it is ten months, better.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Gabriel Mato, and his team for their excellent work, and also Renata Briano for her earlier opinion. Considering the scope and complexity of this matter, the Commission is very pleased that the co-legislators were able to reach a political agreement smoothly and in a spirit of good cooperation and compromise. This is a challenging proposal because this transposition of measures agreed under the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) relates to numerous recommendations adopted since 2008. Some had already been partially implemented through the Control Regulation and the Regulation on illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. A review of some other regulations, including on control measures for highly migratory fish and on the system of statistical monitoring of trade in bluefin tuna, swordfish and bigeye tuna, is therefore also implied. I have read the statement tabled by the Committee on Fisheries for adoption by Parliament on the issue of EU compliance with ICCAT recommendations. I do not want in any way to justify any delays. However, while I agree that we should transpose such measures faster, I would like to clear up immediately a potential misperception that the EU has not been complying with its international obligations. That is clearly not the case. First, following the adoption of the Treaty of the Functioning of the EU, any measures adopted by an international organisation to which the EU is party is binding on the Member States even without transposition. Second, despite some occasional delays in transposition, the EU has always ensured compliance with the international obligations it assumes, and the adoption of the ICCAT transposition regulation will, in the future, permit faster and more efficient implementation of new ICCAT recommendations, thanks to the delegation of certain well-framed powers to the Commission. I strongly support this practical approach, as it will allow the Union to deliver on its international obligations towards the regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) in a timely manner, providing certainty to Member States and a level playing field for operators. The transposition of measures adopted under ICCAT is necessary because they not only impose obligations on Member States but also create obligations for individuals, such as the vessel master and owner. These obligations need to be transposed into EU law to ensure legal certainty and a level playing field for operators across the EU. The ICCAT transposition regulation embraces the series of ICCAT recommendations with the exception of measures concerning the recovery plan for bluefin tuna and Mediterranean swordfish, which are included in separate regulations. The one for bluefin tuna has already been adopted. The Commission is currently finalising a draft regulation for a recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish, which is in internal consultation, and we aim to adopt the proposal before the end of the year. Let me assure you that the Union will continue working with the RFMOs to ensure better ocean governance and more sustainable fishing. We are fully committed to comprehensively and systematically addressing the issue of transhipment at sea within the framework of the RFMOs, with a view to extending the Union prohibition on transhipment at sea from our own to all waters. Thank you for your kind attention and for tabling this important regulation for debate. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the transposition of the ICCAT recommendations is environmentally important, as it includes protective measures for some very vulnerable marine species, such as sharks, seabirds and turtles. Another positive point, wanted by this Parliament, concerns the obligation for Member States to apply transparent and objective criteria in the allocation of bluefin tuna and swordfish quotas: Member States will have to work to distribute national quotas fairly, taking into account traditional artisanal fishing, which is too often penalized. However, I cannot fail to point out that what we are going to vote tomorrow concerns outdated and therefore outdated ICCAT recommendations for some species, with the risk of creating legal confusion: just think of the swordfish recovery plan, on which we are already working, after the decisions of 2016. In this regard, I want to reiterate the disappointment, which I have already expressed with three parliamentary questions, regarding the unfair distribution of swordfish quotas among Member States. The EU has in fact used different distribution criteria in ICCAT and then among the States, which penalize only Italy: also for this announcement, so that, personally, I will not vote in favor of the proposal tomorrow.

name: Werner KUHN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank Gabriel Mato for his report, which he drafted in a very technical and precise manner. Because the International Commission for the Conservation of Tuna Stocks in the Atlantic is of course an organization that goes further than the European Union's fisheries policy. It was founded in 1966 - over 50 years ago - because bluefin tuna was in a very difficult situation in the Atlantic and threatened to collapse. That already means that all the countries bordering the Atlantic Ocean - North Atlantic, South Atlantic - have to work together. These conferences, which are now held annually, refer directly to the stocks we have available to catch bluefin tuna, bigeye tuna, yellowfin tuna and, in a special way, swordfish. We heard it, also from my colleague Briano, that of course there is also a complicated situation in the Mediterranean area here. The European Union with its member states has transferred the negotiating mandate to the Commission, and the Commission is then, so to speak, the authoritative and negotiating institution at this ICCAT conference, which can negotiate the relevant quotas with the individual member states. A delegation from the European Parliament only has observer status there, but then we ultimately have to implement the results - as Gabriel Mato said earlier. The fact that there is a delay of over ten years is simply unacceptable. Commissioner Vella said it again earlier: you will work to improve these periods in the future. It is also the case that control over the fishing vessels that have an ICCAT license and entry in the relevant shipping registers must be improved, including over the possibilities of the Data transmission by satellite etc. It is on the right track, but we must see together that it is precisely this illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, namely illegal fishing in the truest sense of the word, that must be combated. The bluefin tuna and also the other tuna species are back in a stock where one can say: We have a future in this regard. And it is also good that cooperation with China, also with Taiwan and also with Japan has picked up speed again in recent years. When we have a situation where a South Korean shipping register indicates that a fishing vessel, a longliner, has been sold without a license and is trying to catch tuna illegally in African waters that it will be caught there Chain can be placed - these are things where we can really report very positive trends in this regard. But as regards the transhipment ban for catches in the Atlantic or in other waters - our fleet also fishes in the Indian and Pacific Oceans - this is an unjustified competitive advantage for all other ICCAT members who do not have to take it into account. When it comes to controlling the fight against illegal fishing - I have already mentioned this - we have to work much better together, and the distribution of quotas, especially for small-scale and small-scale fishing - this is also included in the basic regulation - must be particularly important to us so that they have a chance of survival there too. Otherwise, as a representative of the EPP Group, I agree to the report drawn up by Gabriel Mato.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, colleague Gabriel Mato, and some shadow rapporteurs, namely Isabelle Thomas and, for ENVI, Renata Briano. The work you have done is important and your speed in this case contrasts with the Commission's slowness. It took almost 10 years for the Commission to fulfill this obligation, leaving the European Union in international default. This transposition of the ICCAT provisions into European law promotes the use of artisanal fishing gear with less environmental impact and local vessels. Portugal, and in particular the Azores, where I come from, has been defending this strategy because it contributes to building and stimulating a fairer, more equitable and more resilient economy. Industrial fishing certainly has its place, but it cannot strangle traditional fishing communities. As the Regulation provides, when allocating possibilities, Member States are called upon to use transparent and objective criteria, including environmental, social and economic criteria, and must provide incentives to European Union fishing vessels using selective or fishing techniques with reduced impact on the environment. I fought for this point of view in this Parliament and in my country on several occasions, namely with regard to the allocation of the rabilo quota for the Azores. As stated now, there should be an obligation to seek to distribute national quotas fairly among the different segments of the fleet, taking into account traditional and artisanal fishing. The new regulation calls for the extension of the ban on transhipments at sea in waters outside the European Union and these positions are in line with the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. We must maintain the position of leader of the European Union in the defense of sustainable development and in combating IUU fishing. In order to guarantee this, it is necessary to reinforce the observer programs, using the full potential of the data collection regulation that we recently approved here. Finally, I want to mention that tuna fisheries in general are in crisis. Every good news is followed by bad news. The large schools of tuna, which used to visit oceanic islands, such as the Azores, have stopped doing so. There may be a set of explanations for this, but I am almost certain that the use of devices for concentrating fish in tropical waters should have its share of responsibility. The use of these devices was rampant in the past but remains excessive in the present and, mainly, these devices continue to be used without the respective environmental impact study. In the Azores, we fish by line and hook, we refuse the use of industrial nets. Each fisherman uses only one hook, and even so, our fisheries were profitable. Not today! It remains for them to solve the problem upstream, ensuring that the springs remain healthy and are able to cross the oceans again. This is in our hands.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Mr President, Honorable Commissioner Vella, colleagues, the protection of marine resources is an important segment of European policies, and the biggest challenge is how to reconcile the interests of fishermen, which we must also consider when adopting new regulations. The situation on the ground is changing very quickly and that is why we must not lag behind if we want to achieve and maintain a balance in the long run between these two goals, which make fishing a sustainable and profitable profession. It is inadmissible for the European Commission to propose the transposition of ICCAT recommendations with a delay of four or nine years, because since then a lot has changed at sea and the people who live from it. I call on the Commission to take time limits into account in its next steps and to react in a timely manner. Since I come from Croatia, I can't help but address the issue of igloo quotas. The Croatian fishing fleet is oriented only to the Adriatic Sea and does not go to other parts of the Mediterranean or to the oceans as is the practice among the fleets of other Member States. The Adriatic Sea is of key importance for the survival of Croatian fisheries, but also of coastal and island communities, which must be taken into account when allocating quotas. Therefore, I would like to express my great opposition to the igloo quotas that have been allocated to us and I ask that they be higher for Croatia, because the ones that have been proposed will deal a great blow to Croatian fisheries.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to regret that it took us ten years to convert these ICCAT recommendations for tunas in the Atlantic into European legislation, something completely beyond the will and usual diligence of the rapporteur for this report, Mr Mato, at I want to thank you for your excellent work. Thus, our credibility and leadership capacity in the field of sustainability and the promotion of good fishing practices has been damaged, both because of the time that has elapsed and because of the obsolescence that some of the recommendations have become. In this way, we can generate legal insecurity such as that which affects, for example, swordfish, with a conservation plan that applies to operators, but which has not yet been transposed into Community legislation despite being a simple process. At least, and thanks to the contributions of the Committee on Fisheries, we have added to the protection and conservation measures some considerations that better connect them with the criteria of the common fisheries policy for the management of fish stocks. Thus, we force ourselves to apply more transparent criteria when allocating catch quotas between Member States. Likewise, we will support artisanal fleets due to their lower impact on the environment and for their decisive contribution to the maintenance of sustainable economic activity and the possibility of obtaining resources in order to diversify sources of income in coastal areas. It is also essential to prioritize the use of low-impact selective gears and not impose additional obligations on European ships over those from third countries; on the contrary, it is necessary for third-country vessels to comply with the same requirements as European vessels, for example in the case of transshipments on the high seas. It is also an advance to incorporate recreational fishing into the scope of application. And finally I don't I will tire of insisting on the need for Member States to accept once and for all the full application of Article 43 (2) and Article 43 (3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, which includes fisheries issues in the legislative procedureordinary and which should favor a more transparent allocation of quotas.We need long-term management plans, with awards based on known and agreed procedures, which are based on reliable scientific data on the state of the stocks and foreseeable quotas in the medium term.This is the best favor we can do to the conservation of species and to the stability of the income of the fishing sector.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Today we are talking about conservation measures for tuna and related species. Many tuna species, such as yellowfin and bigeye tuna, are still threatened by overfishing. There is still great scientific uncertainty for a number of other species. The annual meeting of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) takes place in November. I would like to urge the Commissioner to take the precautionary principle to heart and to propagate it at this upcoming ICCAT meeting. Minimal signs of recovery, as we see with bluefin tuna, for example, are no excuse to increase the fishing pressure already much more. Bluefin tuna is still on the red list of endangered species. I therefore find it irresponsible that the rapporteur is once again getting ahead in the explanatory statement of this report and argues for more catches of bluefin tuna. All the more so because increasing the quota for tuna endangers not only bluefin tuna itself, but also other vulnerable species, such as swordfish and marlin. And we want to protect the latter with these regulations. This report from the Fisheries Commission contains several proposals that go far less than the European Commission proposed. They protect the ecosystem much less. For example, the European Commission wanted to reduce the fishing fleet for bigeye tuna, or at least not to expand it further. The rapporteur wants to abandon this reduction because it is not strictly mandatory. But it is no shame to show a little more ambition. Finally, the sales ban for white and blue marlins caught above quota. They are overfished and the status of these fish species is vulnerable. It is not without reason that hardly any fishing opportunities have been set. The fisheries commission now proposes not to count marlins as they above quota are caught and landed.For example, the animals could be used for scientific research.It may come as a surprise to some, but a fish that has been killed and landed is missing from the ecosystem whether you count it or not.And whether you eat it or examine it: overfishing is not stopped by killed fish, but not counting.Overfishing is stopped by fishing less or even not fishing.And I also believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, you can’t save your money and spend it, you can’t have you cake and eat it, and you can’t pretend to be a nation when you are not. The EU tries to do all three all the time. This report illustrates that perfectly. This is an international convention. The word ‘international’ means between nations. The European Union, despite what it likes to think, is not a nation. It follows that it cannot be – and should not be – a party to such international agreements, this one and many others.  If David Davis has even half a brain, this is an important negotiating card, an ace in the pack, but any card is only as good as how you play it. Happily, we have the perfect opportunity to play it and play it repeatedly. We, the United Kingdom, are permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. We must not give this up. On the contrary, we must start to make better use of it. This means using it to oppose, block and even veto behaviour on international treaties, conventions and agreements which are against our interest. There is a clear UK message here for the European Union: do you think you hold all the cards? You don’t. Our hand is potentially a lot better than you understand. What the UK has to do, however, is to understand itself how good our hand is and then be prepared to use it. If the British Government is worth anything at all, those who play hardball with us should – and, I hope, will – find that we can play hardball with them.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, Dear Commissioner Vella, Dear Colleagues, as is well known, tuna and related species are highly migratory species, exploited by commercial fishing throughout their geographical distribution by fleets of different nationalities, with a very heavy fishing effort. varied and using very different fishing gear. The sustainability of marine biological resources should be a huge concern for all of us. However, I argue that this sustainability must not be blind, that is, it must also take into account long-term economic and social sustainability, and in this sense, I cannot fail to mention the situation of the fishermen and their families, who are going through a crisis situation, lack of income, even working harder and risking their lives a lot. I speak especially of fishermen from coastal areas, from outermost regions such as the Azores, who are increasingly suffering from the scarcity of marine biological resources, that is, fish. That is why this proposal is very important as it arises in the sense that we can balance all these aspects, especially with regard to tuna. Also here, year after year, both fishermen and our tuna industry see fewer and fewer resources, less tuna, undermining the sustainability of this important activity in my region, the Azores, thus threatening hundreds of direct jobs and indirect because, at some point, whether for climatic reasons, which led to the alteration of the migration routes of the tuna, or for human reasons, with aggressive fishing techniques by others that reduce, in large numbers, the individuals who manage to do this migration. Fisheries in the Azores, therefore, are part of the cultural and regional heritage and constitute a highly relevant socio-economic activity. Indeed, the Azoreans are highly dependent on fishing and marine resources play an important role. key role in the local economy and employment, including in fisheries-related industries, including the tuna canning industry. Commissioner, what you are bringing us here today aims to harmonize and broaden the scope of the ICCAT recommendations. I would like to make two very clear messages here: the first involves equal treatment between European and third-country fleets. We cannot continue to impose more restrictive and limiting rules on our fishermen than on other fleets that often do not respect the most basic principles of European standards. The second message is the commitment we ask you to take into account artisanal fleets, especially those in the outermost regions, as is the case in the Azores, as we have been an example at European and world level of the sustainability of tuna fishing. In the Azores, tuna are fished with pole and pole and, in general, with live bait, a highly sustainable fishing technique, with little environmental impact and very selective. Most catches are processed by the locally important tuna canning industry, although fresh tuna is becoming increasingly important because it produces higher prices, especially in the export market. Finally, I would also like to ask you to take into account the possibility of an increase in the shares of bluefin tuna, whose stock is booming and which in fact would be very useful for us to be able to compensate European fishermen for cutting the quotas for swordfish fishing , as is commonly recognized, suffered a sharp deterioration in its stocks. For all the reasons explained above, the growing adoption of information collected and managed by ICCAT is encouraged in order to adopt appropriate management measures and to safeguard the interests of operators in the sector who practice highly sustainable fisheries, as is the specific case of the Azores .

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this regulation aims to transpose the agreement of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, of which the European Union has been a contracting party since 1997, please or not to Mr. Hookem. This agreement covers some thirty species of tuna in the Atlantic and the adjacent seas, which is to say its importance for the management, conservation and control of fishery resources in accordance with the foundations of the common fisheries policy. So on paper everything looks perfect. Except that this is not the 2016 agreement, the most recent, but the 2008 one. We are transposing a text more than nine years late. The Commission has presented us with a transposition project, which is not only nine years old but, moreover, partly obsolete, since a new ICCAT agreement was negotiated in 2016. Thus, while it is about manage a precious resource, both economically and ecologically, while stocks have collapsed or improved depending on the species, and then, above all, when the common fisheries policy is based on the best scientific knowledge and the most recent, Brussels bases its regulations on data ten years old. This is the reason why, at the request of the Socialist Democratic Group, heard by the rapporteur, whom I thank, the Committee on Fisheries unanimously voted for an annexed resolution, denouncing this unacceptable situation which notably excludes swordfish. . Of course, once again, and I am addressing you Commissioner to ensure that this is not the case, the Commission risks proposing a delegated act to update this regulation, which is democratically more than questionable . I will close by recalling that I had presented amendments to include small fisheries, proposing that they could have access to the bluefin tuna quota without compromising relative stability.To facilitate the compromise, we took the old formulations already in existence and, therefore, we can regret that this issue, although sensitive on our coasts, was not taken into account in the final agreement.Delays and lack of discussion deteriorate the interinstitutional dialogue, even if in the end I support the rapporteur and his proposal.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Mato and the shadow rapporteurs on a very successful report, which clearly highlights the need to maintain the principle of equality for European fleets with third country fleets. I am also in favor of the strict transposition of the ICCAT recommendations in order to create a level playing field for all operators. Ensuring a level playing field for all is essential if we want the support of fishermen. I would also like to point out that we must exercise extreme caution when fishing for bluefin tuna and when fishing for an archer in the Mediterranean Sea, which is a very overfished sea in the European Union. The introduction of TACs or TACs as well as other conservation measures, including the wise and prudent use of fishing gear for these species, must be respected by all ICCAT parties. Only joint actions involving third countries will significantly protect these species from excessive fishing pressure and contribute to the stability and sustainable fishing in the region.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the ICCAT whose convention the European Union ratified in 1997, has the technical and scientific responsibility to present specific proposals and recommendations for the conservation and management of tuna fisheries. These are acts essentially directed at the contracting parties, but which also contain obligations directed at private operators, such as ship masters. We have identified two major contradictions in the Commission's position. The first is that the proposal he presented with recommendations and management measures of his own contradicts the spirit of the convention, which aims to transpose those recommendations exactly, guaranteeing the same conditions for all fishermen and fleets in the region. On the other hand, taking into account that the ICCAT recommendations come into force six months after their adoption, it is incomprehensible that the recommendations of 2008 are only being transposed at present, some of which are already out of date, as is the case with the fisheries of the swordfish in the Mediterranean, for which new recommendations were drawn up last November. A delay that highlights the limitations imposed by the fact that Member States have lost to the European Union their capacity to manage marine resources, with inevitable losses for the management of resources at national level but also for the defense of arts that have particular relevance at the regional level, since, being handcrafted, and we give as an example the jump and pole in the Azores or the almadraba in Spain, they lack timely measures that guarantee, in an uncompromising way, their defense and all the historical, social heritage and cultural, in addition to the economic importance for the communities that maintain and practice them. We believe that the proposals as issued by the ICCAT should be maintained, whose management measures ensure fishing opportunities, giving special attention to small-scale and artisanal fisheries, aiming at the sustainability of stocks of tuna.We also believe that the Commission's attempt to pave the way for changes and centralize important decisions through delegated acts is negative.Therefore, it is considered that the direct transposition of the recommendations of regional organizations is a more correct procedure, ensuring greater equity between the different countries.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like, first of all, to congratulate Mr Mato for the work done - I think it is very good - together with the shadow rapporteurs. I think that finally the transposition that is made is adequate. Maybe there is something missing, but I think he has done a great job. My congratulations. The transposition into Union law of these conservation measures is necessary to ensure that vessels comply with the regulations of the ICCAT Commission Convention. Like all of us, we are referring specifically to Atlantic tuna. With this transposition it is also guaranteed that a responsible management of the species regulated by this regional organization is carried out, even if it is outside the area established by the Convention. It is important that both community and non-community fishermen operate under the same rules and that the burden of recovery of the populations does not fall only on a few. I know that we are all insisting on it, but since I live in Spain and I know what happens in the Mediterranean - where, sometimes, the rules of fishermen that we have in the European Union are not the same as those of neighboring countries. , this insistence is important: that all of us who operate in an area have the same standards. By virtue of this Regulation, species as important to the Spanish fleet as bluefin tuna or swordfish are regulated. It is essential to ensure that this management of these populations is carried out in a sustainable manner, without forgetting the socioeconomic aspect or the coastal populations that live from this capture. Both aspects are very important to me. The European Commission, however ... We all say it, but it is true: the delay of these nine, almost ten years, in transposing the twenty-eight recommendations is very striking. A delay that is very difficult to justify and that, in any case, cannot be repeated. Now we have the fish management plan sword, what are we waiting for. It is worth highlighting the importance of these management standards, since currently the bluefin tuna stocks are in very good condition. This is demonstrated by the scientific reports published on the matter, and this is great news. This improvement in stocks is due to good practices in the sector and should translate into an increase in total allowable catches to reward fishermen for the effort they have made contributing to their recovery. In three years, the total allowable catches of bluefin tuna has increased by 60%. The ICCAT, which can regularly review its recommendations and implement new measures, must take into account the future of some fleets: that of swordfish from the entire coastline of Spain —and I especially want to mention the Carboneras fleet, in Almería, which it is undergoing both cuts, swordfish and bluefin tuna. I end by saying: we must stop talking about the recovery of bluefin tuna and, instead, start talking about the management plan.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, tuna and swordfish fishing in the Mediterranean and the Atlantic is of particular importance because it contributes to job creation in many European Union countries. But, Mr Vella, the European Union must react to the unfair practices of third-country fishing fleets, because European fishermen are abiding by what has been agreed, while third-country fishing fleets are literally being pirated. In addition, measures must be taken to support traditional and small-scale fishing, especially in the Mediterranean and Greece; in Greece, where fishermen have been literally impoverished following the troika's brutal tax attack. For this reason, measures must be taken to support Greek fishermen. Finally, Mr Vella, especially now that the Saronic Gulf has suffered enormous ecological damage due to the sinking of the tanker "Agia Zoni II", I ask you to state here what support measures you will take in favor of the Greek fishermen who have huge damage due to this ecological disaster. I want an answer to this question, Mr Vella, because Greek fishermen are waiting for you to tell us how you will support them in tackling this problem that exists today in the Saronic Gulf.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after almost ten years, the Commission is preparing the implementation of the ICCAT recommendations which date back to 2008 and which are therefore obsolete, in particular for Mediterranean swordfish, a species for which ICCAT has adopted last year a multiannual recovery plan which is already applicable since April 2017. The situation is even more unacceptable because the Commission, almost six months after ICCAT approved the recommendation on Mediterranean swordfish, did not it has yet adopted any proposal for transposition, even creating confusion on the reference period for calculating quotas. The Commission needs to act in a more transparent and timely manner for future proposals to transpose the recommendations. The fishing sector does not deserve this superficiality and needs certainties; and that is why, despite the good work done by the speakers, I will not vote in favor of the transposition tomorrow, considering that the criteria used in the latest decisions harm some countries, including Italy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, first I would like to welcome the 28 recommendations for conservation, management and control of fisheries, as they have not yet been covered by EU rules. Even though they are binding, the decisions adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) must be transposed as soon as possible into EU law. The regulation will set out various specific provisions on, for example, tropical tunas, marlins, sharks and swordfish, and will include measures to limit incidental catches of seabirds and turtles. It will also establish a number of common control measures. Taking into consideration that the ICCAT may regularly review its recommendations and decide on new measures, I would like to underline my support for the proposal to give the Commission delegated powers so that such recommendations can be incorporated rapidly into EU law.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that we need to be very careful when we make important decisions which could have serious repercussions on the fisheries sector. The ICCAT recommendations, some of which are really dated, albeit with the general objective of regulating activity and making fishing sustainable, risk imposing new and increasingly heavy obligations on our fishermen, who have been living for years a profound crisis. Before accepting new rules, we should therefore be able to ensure some safeguards. First of all, when allocating fishing opportunities, Member States should distribute national quotas equally between the various fleet segments. In addition, it would be necessary to provide incentives for fishermen, who already make enormous efforts and use selective fishing gears or who use fishing techniques with a reduced environmental impact. Third and last but not least, the ICCAT recommendations should also be observed by non-European countries. For this reason, in thanking the rapporteurs for their work, I believe that, first of all, we must protect the interest of our fishermen.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, this is about the EU approving an international convention. The object is scarcely the point. Do we want to conserve tuna? Of course we do! We want the largest possible breeding stock to deliver the greatest numbers. That is common sense. Whether this agreement will achieve that is debatable at the very best. What is clear is that international conventions are for nations – I repeat – nations to sign. The clue is in the name: nations! Over the weekend we witnessed bloody scenes as Spanish police terrorised the people of Catalonia to stop them expressing their views – the very negation of everything my Group stands for. It is also in our name: Freedom and Direct Democracy! That is our Group. Madrid justifies its behaviour on the grounds that Spanish law is being broken. Putting aside the question as to whether a government should beat up its people in that way, even if they are breaking the law, we are entitled to expect the government that does this to be a stickler for the letter of the law. An international convention is a convention between nations. That means the parties to it should be nations. The EU is not a nation or a state and should therefore not be a party to international agreements – international, may I say.  If the Spanish Government are sticklers for the legal protocol, they should share our view. They do not, of course, because their view of the law is entirely contentious and self-interested. If they were consistent and decent, they would not try to deny the long-standing international agreement of the Treaty of Utrecht, some hundreds of years old. They would not constantly try to bully Gibraltar. To clarify, we – the UK – put our money on democracy where our mouths are. We staged a referendum on Scottish independence, at taxpayers’ expense may I add, and the vote was won for the Union. The Spanish might have done much better to behave as the British did.  We oppose this convention, as ultra vires.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I would say to the speaker who preceded me that the Spanish Government complies with international law, complies with United Nations Resolutions, complies with European Treaties and with the Spanish Constitution. What happens is that this man does not respect the truth, not even the smallest truth. With that said, let's now turn to the serious issues and not the circus issues. On serious issues, I like this transposition because it is faithful to the latest ICCAT Resolution. My only regret is that the transpositions are sometimes carried out so late: it has taken almost ten years, and the measures relating to swordfish are not updated, however, a species that is the subject of a recovery plan, I think approved in 2016. That is why, in short, we had to make this declaration annexed to the Resolution approved by Parliament's Fisheries Committee that highlights these imbalances, and I would like it to be taken into account for future transpositions. And I am going to express one more wish: that, please, take into account the need to increase the quotas for bluefin tuna now, to also compensate for the restrictions that have been established on swordfish. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Stay up because we almost got a blue card from Mr. Iturgaiz on Mr. Coburn, but now Mr. Coburn wants to ask you a question, Mr. Millán Mon, are you okay?

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - If it is a question and not an insult.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Coburn, aren't you going to insult him?

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I would assure the Honourable Gentleman it is not, but I would like to point out that what we did in the United Kingdom – and it was a brave and sensible thing to do, and the right thing to do – was that we had a debate on Scottish independence. I led one side of it – or part of one side of it – and other people led the other. That seemed to be a better way of solving these matters than the way the Spanish Government is doing it now. I am also very pleased to see that the European Union has kept out of this. I talked to Jean-Claude Juncker and he did not want to become involved. I think that is good. But do you not think that my method of doing this or our method ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Coburn, this has nothing to do with debate.You made a commitment not to insult him, but you also had to stay in the debate.Excuse me, but for now I'm in the chair.So we stay in the debate.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: "blue card" response.- Mr Coburn, among the things to learn is that the British Constitution, which is an unwritten text, is different from the Spanish Constitution.Consequently, the Scottish case cannot be compared with the Catalan case, because the Constitutions are different.I repeat: the Spanish Constitution clearly says that the Spanish nation is indissoluble — unique and indissoluble — in its article 2. It has nothing to do with the British text, which does not even exist.Therefore, you cannot mix things that are totally and completely different.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: - Madam President, I would also like to remind Mr Coburn in ten seconds that we have seen many times images of the British police when they have had to go to repel demonstrations, because they represent law and order - the British police, like the Spanish police. ; We have also seen how they have done it in the United Kingdom, and Mr Coburn can give few lessons to the Kingdom of Spain. Madam President, allow me the first thing to do is congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Gabriel Mato, as this report on management, conservation and control measures applicable in the ICCAT Convention area is a complex, time-consuming and long-awaited report. by the fishing sector, since the management and control measures are established, in order to achieve the conservation of the Atlantic tuna. I must remember - as has been said here too - regrettably, that the European Commission has not yet sent any plans on this issue; and a decade has passed since the parliamentary petitions and petitions on this matter from the workers of the sector - the fishermen - who are the ones who are directly suffering from the apathy that is occurring. This is also coupled with the fact that, unfortunately, the quotas for tuna have not been increased, when there is technical and biological data that it can be done. Therefore, we demand from the Commission a favorable response to Mr. Mato's demands.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all those who participated in the debate. It has shown a very broad criticism of the delay but broad support for the approval of this proposal and I am very happy that the negotiations have concluded. Many have stressed the issue of the delayed transposition, which I fully understand. I have already commented on the delay in my introductory remarks. I stress again that the European Union has been complying with its international obligations all along, in spite of the delay in transposition. The EU was never in breach of any law. The adoption of this proposal will also contribute to reducing such delays in the future. This is a milestone that will contribute to a quicker procedure to transpose international obligations, acquired by the Union under regional fisheries management organisations (RFMO), into EU law in a timely manner. I want to stress the fact that the EU fishing industry was never exempt from any measure of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). The European Union is a contracting party to ICCAT since 1997; as such the EU is under international obligation to ensure that the provisions of the ICCAT recommendations are effectively complied with, but pursuant to Article 216(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) this international obligation also lies with Member States. They are bound to comply with the provisions of RFMOs and take necessary measures to this end, even in the absence of transposition of the said measures into EU law. In fact, the Commission was continuously monitoring to ensure that all Member States were adhering to ICCAT obligations and measures. With regards to the use of data, I can assure you all that we are not using ten year old data as was said. I want to assure everyone that all fishing opportunities are evaluated by scientists on the latest data given by all contracting parties.  One comment regarding Mr Marias’ question on what support could be given to fishermen affected by an oil spin – I will take note of this and will revert directly to you to see whether support measures are available under the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). With regards to this regulation, the Commission sees it as an inspiration for future transpositions. It was led by the principle of fair and strict transpositions and it allows for quick implementation of new ICCAT recommendations. As I said, the proposal transposing the management plan for swordfish is expected to reach you during the next months. The issue of quota distribution, which was raised by some MEPs, is not part of this regulation. This has been discussed extensively with Members States both before the ICCAT meeting and also after. We have found a good solution. Madam President, I would like to thank again Mr Mato and Madam Renata Briano for their support and the debate. I am looking forward to a very positive vote in the future.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker. - Madam President, it is only when I listen to Mr Coburn that I see something positive in Brexit. Do you know what it is? That he will not be in this Parliament again. When you talk about freedom and democracy, you can't talk about them if you don't talk about freedom, respect for the laws and the courts. Thanks to everyone, everyone who has intervened, even those who have said that they will not support this project. In any case, what I want to say, Commissioner, is that I accept your commitment to work on the line of going faster. It is obvious, it is necessary. We are now talking about the swordfish plan. He has said that he will be there before the end of the year ... hopefully! It's already a year or so, a long year for me to be here. But, in any case, it's not the nine years we're talking about, and I appreciate it. It is true that he says that there is a false perception, that they have complied ... Man, what we do not know are the consequences. Obviously, being binding, they could have been applied, but, of course, we agree that it is not desirable. And he does not understand the statement, does not see it only as a criticism - which it is, evidently. He must understand it as an incentive, as an alert and as an invitation so that this does not happen again. Mrs. Hazekamp said, regarding the tuna recovery plan, that we could not ask for more quotas. Man, the recovery plan has been totally and absolutely successful. And she told me not to be ashamed to have more ambition. No, I am not at all ashamed to have more ambition. What happens is that I do not know if our ambitions are going the same way, because it is important to impose strict measures when necessary - and this has been done - but it is equally important to reward fishermen for their effort, and that must be done . The commissioner said that, indeed, this is not the reason we are talking about today - the increase in bluefin tuna quotas. But we cannot tell the fishermen that we are speaking of ICCAT, that we are talking about recommendations and that we are talking about swordfish plans, in which quotas are imposed, and, at the same time, we do not say to them «you have made an effort, you have managed to recover thepopulations of this and, therefore, we are going to increase their quotas.Nothing more, President.Nothing more, Commissioner.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The point is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, October 3, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- As the conservation of living marine resources is an exclusive EU policy, there is no other choice for Member States than to act within this framework (or to leave the EU as Greenland didin 1985).This text helps to preserve not only fish stocks in the Atlantic and Mediterranean, but also to protect species of turtles and seabirds threatened by industrial fishing.Unfortunately, states are responsible for many checks, which constitutes a significant administrative burden.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The purpose of the proposal to be put to the vote is to transpose into EU law the conservation, control and enforcement measures adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas in the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas. Should recommendations be made mandatory, because by protecting marine fish stocks and preserving marine biodiversity and ecosystems, we are actually ensuring the future and livelihood of our children and grandchildren, many of whom will hopefully be involved in sea fishing. From this point of view, it must be seen that aquaculture in the EU currently unfortunately plays a secondary role alongside fishing. However, it is clear that sustainable sea fishing is unable to meet humanity's growing demand for fishery products, so the European Union must move towards the development of aquaculture with a qualitative shift. This will increase the sector's competitiveness and reduce Europe's dependence on imports of fishery products. The EU supplies less than 2% of the world's aquaculture fish, but is at the forefront of quality. Work must continue on the basis of this quality, thus helping the sector to grow. This not only means an increase in the number of jobs, but also contributes to improving food security.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: On the agenda is Anna Hedh’s report on the economic empowerment of women in the private and public sectors in the Union (2017/2008 (INI)) (A8-0271 / 2017).

name: Anna HEDH
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! Even though Europe is a world leader in women's rights and gender equality, we still have a lot to do. As President Tajani said when he opened the part-session, we in this House have an enormous responsibility for women's rights, and can make a difference. That is why I am pleased to be able to present today my report on women's economic empowerment in the private and public sectors in the EU. In today's Europe, we see inequality clearly between men and women in our everyday lives, whether it is the gender-based wage gap, the pension gap, responsibility for unpaid domestic work or harassment in the workplace. In the work with gender equality, economic self-determination is a central issue and something we must always take into account when we try to achieve change. One of the main factors limiting people is economic vulnerability, and women are overrepresented in both poverty and economic dependence. One result of this is the wage gap and the subsequent pension gap, which is unfortunately still alarming. The wage gap between men and women is 16.5 per cent in the EU, which in turn has resulted in a 40% pension gap, while the gap in employment between men and women costs the EU around € 370 billion a year. In addition, today 17 million women in the EU are involuntarily excluded from the labor market due to precarious working conditions. We must ensure that women's employment is secure and give them the right to full-time employment. In addition, we need to tackle the unpaid homework that women in the EU spend 24 hours more than men. I want to see an end to this and I believe that an important way forward for gender equality is about economic self-determination. The road there is not easy and we must dare to think broadly and long-term. But I think my report can be indicative. Before the vote tomorrow, there are certain things in my report that I would like to press extra, and which we actually agreed on in committee. Despite that, so EPP and ALDE are now trying, as usual, to remove these important issues. Some of them are the wage gap between men and women, which must end. Therefore, I propose wage surveys and that the social partners should work for higher wages in sectors where women make up a majority of the workforce, that the macroeconomic trends we have today must be reconsidered. We need a gender perspective on economic policy. This was clearly felt during the economic crisis, when austerity measures hit women particularly hard. Men's violence against women is one of today's major security problems. We must put an end to the patriarchal notions that have resulted in women dying. And we must ensure that everyone has access to sexual and reproductive health and rights. The right to decide over one's own body must never be restricted. We are only three years away from 2020, where we ourselves have set very high goals that we must achieve. We cannot accept failure and must continue to work for women's empowerment and participation in the labor market. We must show leadership by taking a firm stance that we do not tolerate inequality and that we also expect both the public and private sectors to take responsibility for the lack of equality, which is spreading due to the problems raised in it. here is the report that we will be voting on tomorrow. I would like to thank everyone who has taken part in the work on this report, both Members and officials. It has been a fantastic job to work with you.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, women and men have equal rights and yet women are in a weaker economic position, have lower incomes and less representation in management positions. It is unfair to women and inefficient for society. So it is right that we look for ways to support women. We must strictly insist on the principle of equal pay for equal work and the enforcement of anti-discrimination legislation. I also personally appreciate the European Commission's latest proposal, which aims to improve opportunities for both children to share childcare. Nevertheless, I did not vote in favor of the draft report we are currently discussing in the FEMM Committee. We cannot improve a woman's economic status just by sending women to work and preventing them from having children and being mothers. That would be a big mistake. We will improve the economic position of women by providing them with a quality education, by financially rewarding their childcare during maternity and parental leave. By enabling mothers to apply their education and continue their profession when employers are motivated to work part-time. We will support the economic status of women by recognizing the value of their motherhood and allowing free choice of parental and professional careers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the progress made in recent years, the potential workforce of women is still far from being fully and optimally utilized. The overall employment rate of women is still 12% lower than that of men and therefore, even in Europe, women suffer a considerable socio-economic gap compared to men: they are underpaid and often underestimated compared to their male colleagues and they are still under-represented in decision-making posts, especially in business and politics. The International Labor Organization also stresses the persistence of a gender gap in women's pay. In short, although work is increasingly becoming an important aspect of female identity, there is still a long way to go to achieve true equality between men and women.
