The true revolution of Europe in favor of gender equality is measured, in my opinion, also at the cultural level, by combating gender discrimination in any form it presents itself. This, I think, is one of the main challenges of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, it is well known that there is a specific socio-economic framework of strong barriers to women 's economic empowerment. The data show that in the workplace there remains a huge wage gap between the two sexes, amounting to 16.4% to the detriment of women, while respectively the pension gap amounts to 39%. Given that women are employed in flexible forms of employment, this means that their pension rights are becoming even lower. In addition, it should be borne in mind that the total employment of women is 12% lower than that of men. According to Eurostat, the current average number of women on the boards of large listed companies is just 23.9%. Moreover, in Greece, where the memoranda have literally dissolved Greek society, women are the group of the population that has been most affected. That is why measures are needed to support women, especially women in Greece, especially the young peasant woman.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Madam President, I wanted to thank the rapporteur for her work with this report and, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I wanted to point out that I am very satisfied, especially in some aspects, such as recognizing that the structural barriers curbing women's economic empowerment have their roots in many overlapping forms of inequality and discrimination, and therefore responses have to be comprehensive. I want to talk about the need to modify and promote the care sector, a sector occupied mainly by women. There are reports from the International Conference of Trade Unions that suggest that, investing 2% of the gross domestic product, in many European countries could generate an increase in employment of between 2 and 6% in this sector, and at the same time dignify it, improve it. quality and combat precariousness. In this sense, it is necessary that we now propose equal and non-transferable paternity and maternity leave, which equitably redistribute care between men and women, in addition to a series of measures ... (The president withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I believe in equality of opportunity, I oppose any gender-based discrimination. The best candidate should be chosen at the same pay – irrespective of gender, religion, sexuality, ethnicity or pretty much anything else. In fact where the private sector is concerned, whenever they choose the wrong person for a job by discriminating, they effectively discriminate against themselves because it hits their own effectiveness, and consequently hits their profits.  But where I diverge from this report is I do not consider equality of outcome to be an appropriate measure in and of itself of non-discrimination, because outcomes are based on a host of other factors. Not least that more men or more women might be more interested in a particular job or have different life and career goals, and in my view society should not measure that – it is none of the state’s business how we choose to approach work – but what we should do is stand against illegal and unfair discrimination.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President, in reading paragraphs 44 and 45 of this report, I recalled the words of the recently deceased Simone Veil, which we so often mention in this House.Citing her bill to legalize abortions in France, she said: "No woman is happy to have an abortion.Just listen to women.It has always been and will remain a tragedy.Therefore, although this bill takes into account existing facts, although it accepts the possibility of abortion, its main goal is to control it and, where possible, discourage women. ”If an unwanted pregnancy worsens a woman's position at work, there are a thousand ways we canto solve.However, abortion is not one of them because it degrades the value of a woman's life and that of her child.Therefore, I cannot support the report.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am glad that many men have spoken on such a subject, and I hope that they will be able to influence their countries in equal opportunities. Women's ability and intelligence are resources that should not be ignored. Studies, as the report shows, show that if we improve this equality of opportunity, we could, by 2050, increase by more than ten million jobs. Equal opportunities do not have to be a statistic. But here we are also talking about education and I will vote wholeheartedly for this report, but Commissioner, I think we need to see how it is transposed into national law and how education is correlated, because we still have barriers and mentalities in both women and men, precisely because of the precariousness of education. We must support the woman to take the job she wants, but to be paid, to be paid at the same job with the same salary if she has the same responsibility.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the encroachment of the legislator into the private sphere to the extent that they recommend this and similar reports is inherent in totalitarian regimes, not democratic systems. It is not a matter of policy how the spouses will distribute the household chores and how much each of them will devote to the children. It is a matter of agreement within the family with which the state should have absolutely nothing. Women must have the same starting position in the market as men and should be judged on the basis of their competencies, not gender. I myself was a victim of discrimination and went through a difficult journey to be treated like my male colleagues. In the end, I defeated the system with my ability and perseverance, not by someone’s grace. Quotas are humiliating for women because they automatically label them less valuable, and serve only certain circles to more easily achieve their political goals. The so-called The Istanbul Convention openly promotes gender ideology and that is why I hope that Croatia will not ratify it.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, I have listened with great interest to what the lady said, I have looked at the report and I am looking forward to reading it more. I myself am a rampant feminist: my grandmother was a suffragette. I do not agree with everything the report says, may I say, but I hope she has looked into the BBC – the British Broadcasting Corporation – an organisation which consistently trumpets its left-wing credentials and, dare I say, progressive, whatever that might mean, and in spite of that, the salary differentials in the BBC between ladies and gentlemen are absolutely blatant. I encourage you to look into them. They are letting down the cause of meritocracy and, dare I say it (it is not a word I generally use), egalitarianism. So I do hope you will look into the BBC. What is going on there is something worth looking at – a lot of hypocrisy. I hope you will do that.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! First of all, I congratulate the rapporteur for this report on taking up a very important topic concerning the presence of women in the labor market and the economic strengthening of women. In fact, we are talking about incentives for women here, we should be talking not so much about incentives, but about stopping women from throwing obstacles in the end, so that finally these visible and invisible barriers on the labor market disappear, so that there is no wage gap, glass ceilings to avoid a retirement gap and a host of other things women have to deal with when they enter the labor market. Today we have an employee market in the European Union. There is an increasing shortage of workers and an estimated 27 million over the next several years. This gap could be smaller if women could work, but there are no nurseries, no kindergartens, no nursing homes as many as they should be, and therefore these goals coincide and therefore we should finally do something.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I congratulate my colleagues, and particularly Anna Hedh, on this report on women’s economic empowerment. It is a great example of the progressive consensus-based policy-making that happens in this House, which makes it such an important institution in the world today. The report highlights many important actions that are required in order to empower women: significantly, education, overcoming discrimination in the workplace and fighting against violence against women. I would specifically like to highlight the enormous potential of social enterprises and cooperatives to provide opportunities to those women who are most vulnerable and marginalised in our society, and those who suffer intersectional discrimination and social exclusion, such as refugees, asylum seekers, disabled women, LGBTI women, Roma women and women in rural areas.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Ms. President! Increasing the economic participation of women is a desirable tool in making our societies fairer, but better reconciliation of the world of work and family life is essential for this. To this end, Member States must also do much to improve the existing legal framework, make the various forms of employment more flexible, and support part-time and teleworking. Today, there are Member States in the EU where the proportion of these forms of flexible working is still negligible. Moreover, in Romania, the government has introduced that companies now pay the same amount of public charges for their part-time employees as they do for their full-time employees. This is by no means a measure to strengthen the position of women in the labor market in a country which, moreover, still lags far behind other Member States and its commitments to the EU in terms of employment.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, in my community of Lancashire there are women earning up to 27% less than men for the same work. In fact, the National Centre for Social Research named two communities in my constituency in the 10 worst local economies in the UK to be women. The EU and Member States acknowledge the problem, but we are crippled by slow progress. One analysis this year estimates that, at the current pace, the UK pay gap will not be eradicated until 2069 – that will be 99 years after the introduction of the Equal Pay Act. This is a holistic problem that touches education, affordable childcare, support for carers and boardroom gender equality. At its heart, it is a problem of basic dignity at work for women everywhere. Please let’s not let progress stall. My constituents cannot afford to wait until 2069.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madame la Présidente, en effet, j'ai souhaité intervenir car ce sujet est important pour tout le monde, c'est pourquoi tous les membres de ce Parlement, les hommes y compris, doivent pouvoir s’exprimer sur ce rapport.  I would like to welcome the call for concrete action for women’s economic empowerment in the private and public sectors in the EU for equal pay between men and women for equal work and work of equal value. I believe that the draft on women’s economic empowerment is right and smart at the same time, because it is enhancing a better-quality work-life balance. We should step up towards concrete legislation that includes gender perspective, which does not necessarily equate to empowerment without including measures to combat all forms of gender-based violence. Finally, it is accurate to state that gender equality and gender balance is an incontrovertible fundamental right in the better integration of women in the labour market and can lead only to property and economic growth.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Anna Hedh on her approach to this report.In a constantly evolving society, I believe that education is the most important tool for women to be able to participate fully in social and economic development, in order to find a quality job.One of the key actions to achieve this goal is to strengthen policies and increase investment in education and training, to promote the sectors and functions in which women are under-represented in order to increase their employment rate in such positions.In addition, entrepreneurship training is essential, coupled with training and support in accessing alternative sources of funding and business networking opportunities to launch their own or collaborative businesses based on innovative ideas.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Anna Hedh, the rapporteur of this report. Women’s equal participation in the labour market and in economic decision-making are preconditions for women’s empowerment. The Commission’s strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019 identifies five priority areas for action. 1: increasing female labour market participation and the equal economic independence of women and men; 2: reducing the gender pay earnings and pension gaps and thus fighting poverty among women; 3: promoting equality between women and men in decision-making; 4: combating gender-based violence and protecting and supporting victims; and 5: promoting gender equality and women’s rights across the world. In this context, let us focus on two important aspects. First, closing the gender employment gap. Women remain significantly under-represented in the labour market. In 2016, women’s employment rate was still more than 10 points lower than men’s employment rate. If you look at the full-time equivalent employment rate, the gap reaches 18 points. This gap is not related to professional qualifications or academic achievement, where women more and more out-perform men. It is first and foremost related to the way women and men share caring responsibilities in our society. The Commission has developed an extensive package of measures contributing to the economic empowerment of women. The main objective of our proposal for a directive on work-life balance of working parents and carers is to address women’s under-representation in the labour market. The proposed directive aims at modernising the current EU legal and policy frameworks for family-related leave and flexible working arrangements. The proposed directive is complemented with non-legislative measures with the objective to promote the development of formal care services; the enforcement of the rules with regard to dismissal; protection for pregnant women; and removing economic disincentives for second earners to work. We are also developing the relevant indicators in order to be able to measure progress in all these areas. The second aspect to focus on when it comes to the economic empowerment of women is closing the gender pay gap. The gender pay gap has been decreasing only slowly and seems to have stabilised at 16% over the last years as a result of pervasive segregation on the labour market, persistent stereotypes fuelled by inadequate work-life balance policies, and discrimination, all of this combined with a lack of transparency. The effective application of the existing legal framework on equal pay remains a challenge in all Member States. The Commission constantly monitors whether EU law on equal pay is applied correctly and supports Member States and other stakeholders in the proper enforcement of the existing rules. We are now finalising – and intend to propose – an action plan to tackle the gender pay gap from all possible angles. It will aim, in particular, at improving the application of the equal-pay principle, combating segregation in occupations and sectors, combating vertical segregation, and recognising women’s skills, efforts and responsibilities.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, October 3, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Although the EU is a world leader in the field of women's rights and gender equality, we have not yet achieved full equality in terms of women's participation in the labor market, wages and pensions, political representation and economic, etc. The EU needs to adopt concrete measures as soon as possible to enhance the empowerment of women, because only when we achieve economic independence for all women can we achieve gender equality. There is a need to improve work-life balance, achieve a more balanced distribution of unpaid work between men and women, improve pay transparency and pay mapping through binding provisions to achieve equal pay for equal and equal work courage, demand that companies negotiate plans on gender equality to reinforce equal opportunities and combat discrimination, guarantee equal representation in the teams that intervene in collective bargaining, increase the participation of women in decision-making , promote the use of gender quotas and zipper lists in political decision-making and eradicate gender violence.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - Statistics show that the EU has not yet made significant progress towards gender equality. So far, we are seeing only a negligible increase in equality. Despite the fact that women have a higher level of education than men, the pay gap between men and women is stark at 16.1%. The amount of pensions differs even more - 40.2 percent. A major problem is the unequal distribution of unpaid work in the household. When unpaid domestic work is done for both men and women, and the burden is shared equally, women will be able to participate in the labor market as men, creating a better basis for a proper work-life balance and thus enabling women to compete on an equal footing. This will not only guarantee people's rights, but also bring economic benefits. In order to strengthen women's economic power, it is first and foremost necessary to ensure that everyone is paid equally for work of equal value. Also, in sectors where women predominate, workers must be paid more. In the case of company boards and the public sector, where high-level decisions are made, the experience of women's participation shows positive results. The Council is therefore called upon to adopt the directive on women on company boards as a matter of urgency. Businesses and various institutions are called upon to adopt gender equality plans that help reduce inequalities in the workplace: addressing employment, pay, career, training and work-life balance issues, as well as preventing sexual harassment.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - Although the EU is a world leader in women's rights and gender equality, we have not yet achieved full equality in terms of women's participation in the labor market, wages and pensions, political representation and economic, etc. The EU needs to adopt concrete measures as soon as possible to enhance the empowerment of women, because only when we achieve economic independence for all women can we achieve gender equality. There is a need to improve work-life balance, achieve a more balanced distribution of unpaid work between men and women, improve pay transparency and pay mapping through binding provisions to achieve equal pay for equal and equal work courage, demand that companies negotiate plans on gender equality to reinforce equal opportunities and combat discrimination, guarantee equal representation in the teams that intervene in collective bargaining, increase the participation of women in decision-making , promote the use of gender quotas and zipper lists in political decision-making and eradicate gender violence.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: written. - Although the EU is a world leader in the field of women's rights and gender equality, we have not yet achieved full equality in terms of women's participation in the labor market, wages and pensions, political representation and economic, etc. The EU needs to adopt concrete measures as soon as possible to enhance the empowerment of women, because only when we achieve economic independence for all women can we achieve gender equality. There is a need to improve work-life balance, achieve a more balanced distribution of unpaid work between men and women, improve pay transparency and pay mapping through binding provisions to achieve equal pay for equal and equal work courage, demand that companies negotiate plans on gender equality to reinforce equal opportunities and combat discrimination, guarantee equal representation in the teams that intervene in collective bargaining, increase the participation of women in decision-making , promote the use of gender quotas and zipper lists in political decision-making and eradicate gender violence.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: written. - Women are still under-represented in the labor market in the European Union. The total labor participation of women in 2017 is still 12 percent lower than that of men. My colleague Hedh's report gives several reasons for this major difference. As long as not working or working less is not a free choice, that is unacceptable to me. That is why I like to look at the solutions to close this gap. This draft resolution offers a number of good tools. For example, there should be instruments for governments and the business community that lead to more wage transparency. This should reduce the pay gap between men and women. The so-called Barcelona criteria must also be met. As a result, families can opt for high-quality affordable childcare earlier, so that the labor participation of women can increase. In my opinion, there are roughly two schools of thought in this debate. The first school argues that inequality between men and women will naturally disappear. The second movement is now trying to close the gap. If calculations show that it will take until the end of this century to close the gap at the current rate, then you will understand that I want to close this gap now.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - Only half of us women in the EU work full time. A continent that should set an example to the rest of the world excludes half of women from the workforce. The situation is not improving. Women are born poorer, live poorer, and die poorer than men. Women are under-represented in the labor market throughout the EU. The overall employment rate for women is still almost 12% lower than for men. 32 per cent of working women work part-time, only eight per cent of men. Are we cheating on European women? We argue that education is the way to better wages. Despite the fact that the level of education of women in the EU is now higher than that of men on average, the gender pay gap is still 16%. Thus, women do not rise to men’s wages, even though they are better educated. We also argue that working a lot can get a lot of pay. That, too, is a scam. Women do more work than men. The difference is that men are paid for most of the work they do. In the EU, women do at least two and a half times more unpaid domestic and care work than men. It’s a real job, but women aren’t paid for it. When work done at home and at work is added together, women’s working days are longer. The big reason for the current situation is that women take care of children and the elderly at home significantly more than men. This needs to be remedied through attitude education, but also through legislation at European and Member State level. The proposals in this report should be taken very seriously.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - Although the EU is a world leader in the field of women's rights and gender equality, we have not yet achieved full equality in terms of women's participation in the labor market, wages and pensions, political representation and economic, etc. The EU needs to adopt concrete measures as soon as possible to enhance the empowerment of women, because only when we achieve economic independence for all women can we achieve gender equality. There is a need to improve work-life balance, achieve a more balanced distribution of unpaid work between men and women, improve pay transparency and pay mapping through binding provisions to achieve equal pay for equal and equal work courage, demand that companies negotiate plans on gender equality to reinforce equal opportunities and combat discrimination, guarantee equal representation in the teams that intervene in collective bargaining, increase the participation of women in decision-making , promote the use of gender quotas and zipper lists in political decision-making and eradicate gender violence.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Whether in businesses, as entrepreneurs or employees, or by doing unpaid care work at home, women make enormous contributions to economies. Therefore, their economic empowerment is an essential element of gender equality, further boosting growth and prosperity. But while the EU is a world leader when it comes to women’s rights, it is unacceptable that it still lags behind as regards to their participation in the labour market and in economic decision-making. Given that women are the most affected by austerity, cuts and, unfortunately, violence, we need binding measures on pay transparency at work, and policies to tackle all forms of gender-based abuses. I am happy that the present report makes bold and necessary recommendations as to how to empower women. As a member of TRAN Committee, I fully support women’s equal participation on the labour market, particularly in areas normally associated with men, such as transport, where only two out of ten workers are female. All sectors need to create better opportunities for women, but the transport sector is one of the sectors that can bring new opportunities, especially in the age of digitalisation and automation. Women empowerment is the only way to dismantle stereotypes and break barriers.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Today, within the European Union, there is still a gap of 12% between the employment rate of men and that of women. The reasons for this unequal situation are many and varied, but they require comprehensive and ambitious measures. Not only is this a shame for modern democracies such as ours which uphold the principles of equality, but it also corresponds to an economic aberration! Indeed, according to the OECD, "Promoting gender equality and women's employment could lead to considerable economic gains in OECD and G20 countries." An improvement in the situation of nearly ¾ of women by 2025 could correspond to an increase in world GDP equivalent to that of the euro area, or 12 trillion euros. Measures such as equal pay for equal work, a balance between men and women in the private and public sectors or the promotion of gender equality are all steps in the right direction, but this is only the case. a beginning! It is high time that our countries, our leaders, take their responsibilities and effectively fight against gender inequalities!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the report by Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, on the shrinking space for civil society in developing countries (2016/2324 (INI) (A8-0283 / 2017).

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: speaker. - Madam President, this is an initiative report of great importance for civil society in developing countries and also for the European institutions. Before dwelling on the most important points in this report, I would like to underline the unanimous position that all political groups have held in dealing with the situation of civil society in developing countries. I have also seen the importance of joint work and consensus to achieve a good result, and thanks to that good will, because of the importance that this report had, we were able to approve it with 22 votes in favor, one abstention and one vote against. It is a very timely and relevant report, as it reflects the reality of civil society in many developing countries that receive assistance from the European Union. I have had the opportunity to meet with the NGOs working on site, to hear the problems and difficulties they face. I have also had the opportunity to meet with representatives of the European Commission and the European External Action Service and they have also allowed me to see another lens of the challenges that must be faced in the European Union in order to help the most disadvantaged. We all agree that human rights, the rule of law and democracy must be respected. Civil society in developing countries is so weak that it needs all of our action and attention. I have seen the difficulties experienced by aid workers, journalists, human rights defenders; inadmissible situations that, on many occasions, lead them to death. There are also very desperate situations in countries in conflict. I am thinking of Africa, where aid workers and civil society suffer the scourge of terrorism on a daily basis. Throughout this text, it has been my intention to underline the value of civil society to preserve a more democratic, dignified and just society, also collaborating positively with the public sector and the private sector. On the other hand, it is of the utmost importance, and this is reflected in the report, the recognition of the action of the European Union, since it defends and enhances the role of civil society in development cooperation. The initiatives could be grouped into two parts. The first, political support, where various measures are proposed, such as regular meetings with members of civil society in the framework of official visits - when the deputies go in delegation, I personally have the presidency, to a country, I always reserve a space to serve all NGOs. Also regularly incorporate this issue on the agenda of the Councils on Foreign Affairs. Also the promotion of the coherence of the policies in the matter of human rights, development, justice and security. Also the creation of a monitoring and early warning mechanism in relation to the reduction of space in civil society. The second initiative concerns financial support. It is recalled that the European Union is the main donor of aid to civil society organizations in developing countries, but we ask that the funds of the instruments dedicated to this be increased, such as the European instrument on human rights and the instrument of development cooperation. It also insists on the need for greater synergies between all the instruments, requesting a follow-up, country by country, of all the activities in support of civil society financed by the European Union. In conclusion, I would like again to emphasize before this House the unity of opinion in the work carried out in the parliamentary committee. Certainly some parts do not meet one hundred percent of the expectations of those of us who have worked on it, but I believe that in the dialogue held, common sense and availability to do a good job have prevailed. For that reason, I ask for the support of this House, because I believe that we must launch an important message, loud and clear, to this threatened civil society in many countries of the world.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Jiménez-Becerril Barrio for a very good report. The worrying trend of shrinking space for civil society in developing countries is definitely a topic that needs to be publicized and sustained. Especially that the European Union is the largest donor of development aid, through which values ​​such as democracy, good governance and fundamental rights are promoted in partner countries. It is important that governments, political parties and administrations in developing countries, instead of restricting such organizations and harassing human rights defenders, be able to cooperate effectively with them. Therefore, it is crucial to promote initiatives for closer dialogue between the government side and civil society organizations, local government representatives and the private sector. I hope that the problem of the diminishing space for civil society will be mainstreamed into the foreign policy of the European Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I want to congratulate the rapporteur from the outset because, indeed, it is a report that we all need. I agree that civil society is the third sector of a democratic, decent, healthy society, alongside the public and private sectors. Civil society can play an important role in strengthening democracy, monitoring state power, and promoting good governance. I understand the concern expressed in some cases of restricting the space of civil society. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that there is a direct link between the level and quality of education and the integrity, quality and efficiency of civil society. That is why I believe, Commissioner, that we need to have related programs through which we can ensure the education of the population, because civil society is really who? - the population. Perhaps there are examples in developing countries where, among civil society, the so-called civil society, we have cases of corrupt people who act in the opposite direction to democracy. That's why I see the two related programs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the role of civil society in developing countries is particularly important because it can really support the development of democracy in these countries, support the very defense of human rights, which are really affected in these countries. We must therefore recognize the special role of civil society. This is also mentioned in the Cotonou Agreement. Obviously, there is concern about the shrinking of civil society. The European Union must take concrete action, in particular to support the efforts of the church and trade unions. However, I would like to point out that there is another side to civil society. There are organizations involved in both development and European Union funding projects in developing countries and refugee issues. There is literally a "party" and there should be direct control of the European Commission itself as to how NGOs manage European funds.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I do not of course disagree with the importance of civil society. I quote from the report and I support the principle of ‘a genuinely independent pluralistic and vibrant civil society’. Where civil society is shrinking in developing countries, then of course we need that to be reversed.  Where I think I perhaps differ from the rapporteur is in two senses. Firstly, I think there is a hint of top—down action here: a supranational institution working together with national governments, to my mind, is something that is less valuable than organisations developing organically from the ground up within communities with the support of NGOs. Secondly, the overall tone of this report seems to be pushing in a direction of more and more harmonisation. Again, I think that is perhaps to an extent contrary to the aims that it is setting out to achieve.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the insidious and destabilizing role of NGOs and so-called civil society organizations is strengthened by the help of political puppets, at national and EU level, which fund and promote them. Already since the "Rose Revolution" in Georgia and the "Orange Revolution" in Ukraine, it has become apparent in practice that NGOs market their selective and dishonest actions perfectly, insidiously promoting supposedly progressive practices and left-wing ideologies of human rights defenders. These organizations directly challenge values ​​and institutions, deconstruct the history of nations, moral traditions, the Christian faith, and violently alter ethnically homogeneous societies by promoting illegal immigration. Those politicians who support them, capitalize on their support through the immunity and acquittal of any criminal prosecution, such as the former Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou, who illegally funded NGOs of friends and relatives with huge sums, while at the same time dragging the Greek people into the whirlpool of memoranda.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting this report, because in my opinion she has very well defined the issues that have already been mentioned here. In my opinion, this colleague, my colleague, passed really well. I see the value of civil society in those developing countries as the real heart of democracy, as a truly key value that we should help to develop. The role of the European Union in these countries is absolutely indispensable, and we should not help these entities only in the diplomatic part, but, of course, in the financial part, as my colleague mentioned. And that our active defense will then pay off for us precisely with regard to international diplomatic relations. I am convinced that if we are well able to target our development aid to these countries and to support these developing societies, it will pay off for us in the long term.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I am very glad to see this report come before Parliament at this time because when we look around the world we see civil societies face ever-increasing attacks from governments around the world in every region, including here in Europe. The European Union is a union of values and peoples, and it needs to rise to this challenge by investing seriously in the promotion of democracy, human rights and the rule of law around the world.  We talk a lot about tackling the root causes of the crises we face – the root causes of migration, radicalisation and instability – but supporting democratic civil society groups, NGOs and human rights defenders around the world is a key foreign policy priority for the EU, and it is really important that we invest in these vital grassroots groups. It is vital for all our futures.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: - Madam President!If High Representative Mogherini does not resolutely protect human rights, it will hit us in the heart of Europe.In all regions of the world, governments are taking massive action against civil society.They have dirty methods of silencing activists: from bureaucratic harassment to account freezes, from arrests to violence.If we want to deal seriously with our values such as freedom of expression, then we must no longer watch as the repression against civil society increases, outside of Europe, but also within European borders.The people's freedom of action is the basis of democracy.And what should the High Representative do now?It must address every attack against civil society in the partner countries in the political dialogue and it must denounce it resolutely.Human rights are not a commodity, not negotiable, not even in deals with Egypt and Ethiopia.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in developing countries there is a worrying increase in reports of persecution, harassment, stigmatization, detention or arbitrary arrest of activists and members of civil society organizations. In some countries this happens with complete impunity, sometimes with the complacency or approval of the authority. In many developing territories, the work carried out by associations and NGOs is irreplaceable: they are human rights defenders - lawyers, intellectuals, journalists and peacemakers - who put their lives at risk to contribute to civil and material progress. of a population. The problem must be addressed by adopting policies aimed at denouncing, in a systematic and unequivocal way, any attempt to subject European operators to any form of violence or persecution. But more must also be done, namely a global approach that makes the procedures for accessing funds made available by Europe more flexible and simplified. Only in this way will the European institutions take on a central role in supporting civil society organizations.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Committee on Development and, in particular, the rapporteur, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, and the shadow rapporteurs for presenting this forward-looking report with very useful recommendations on how we can address the worrying trend of shrinking space for civil society in certain countries. This is a reality that we must tackle together as it is the only way development cooperation will bear fruit. The European Union is seeking to formulate coherent and effective responses – building on the experience gathered so far. We are increasing our efforts in preserving civil space and ensuring an enabling environment for civil society organisations. Clear expressions of our strong commitment are: the Commission’s communication on Europe’s engagement with civil society in partner countries from 2012, the EU Global Strategy on Foreign and Security Policy and our new European Consensus on Development. They all emphasise the crucial role of civil society as actors of governors and development.  Overall, your report is in line with the thinking and the ongoing work of the Commission and the High Representative to strengthen our support to civil society organisations and to continue our engagement in promoting their greater autonomy. EU delegations are at the forefront of translating EU policies into concrete actions on the ground. Therefore they proactively identify and report on threats to civil society space, including reprisals, and take steps to counter such threats. This implies using all of our diplomatic tools throughout the world, human rights dialogues and high-level contacts to raise the cases of individuals at risk. Supporting a genuinely independent, diverse, pluralistic and vibrant civil society is essential to help achieve the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. We are committed to investing more in existing good practices and highlighting the positive aspects of the Sustainable Development Goals’ implementation through civil society organisations. The Commission and the High Representative are engaging with EU partner countries through various channels. When it comes to development cooperation, we support partner countries through funding that focuses on engagement with civil society and by ensuring consistency between all relevant EU policies and activities. However, I would like to emphasise that the support to our partner countries is not only financial. Our relations with civil society organisations are, first and foremost about policy dialogue, hence the need for appropriate space for them to share their views. The Commission will continue engaging with various stakeholders to drive this agenda forward and the European Parliament is one of our essential partners. Building trust and continuing to work closely with all relevant actors is key to addressing the challenges faced by civil society.  As you know, the EU Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders were adopted in 2008. We consider human rights defenders as one of the cornerstones of every well—functioning state and are key allies in the promotion of the democratisation and expansion of civil space. Providing support and giving them visibility has been, and remains, one of the major priorities of the EU’s external human rights policies.  The progress and achievements since 2012 are reflected in the Commission’s report on EU engagement with civil society in external relations, which was issued in April this year. It provides concrete examples of how the EU is acting on its priorities with regard to civil society, showing the diversity, complementarity and strength of the EU’s worldwide interventions in support of civil society. The report was followed by Council conclusions last June, which confirm that on this essential point all EU institutions stand united.  The Commission and the High Representative are committed to continue working closely with the European Parliament and EU Member States to ensure that together we can build a better environment for civil society organisations. By preventing the further shrinking of civil space, we are not only enabling civil society organisations to engage more effectively as development actors, but we are living up to our duty to defend the values of democracy, freedom, pluralism and solidarity.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, October 3, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I welcome the report as it puts the spotlight on the central role that civil society plays in ensuring democratic consolidation, social justice and respect for human rights as well as in promoting accountability and good governance. Whereas clamping down on civil society organisations is getting more difficult to address, we need to step up efforts and provide guidance to beneficiary countries on strategies for creating adequate legal, administrative and political environment, which allows to these key actors to work efficiently. Civil society actors including human rights defenders and development NGOs must always possess the space to operate free from intimidation, harassment, violence and undue bureaucratic burdens. Moreover, in line with the EU’s long—standing commitment to civil society in developing countries, I strongly believe that we have to boost our engagement through increased and diversified funding modalities and mechanisms.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – Restrictions on civil society have become increasingly repressive. To counterbalance this fact the report brings forward positive proposals to guarantee the role NGOs play in fostering democracy and the well-being of citizens worldwide. However, in order not to jeopardise the development of free and diverse civil societies, and in line with policy coherence for development, we believe it is fundamental for the EU to establish legal human rights obligations for business. In addition, we believe in free and independent civil societies, but deplore the strong reference the report makes to religion or faith-based movements. We will therefore abstain from supporting this resolution.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Elissavet Vozemberg-Vrionidi, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the fight against cybercrime (2017/2068 (INI)) (A8-0272 / 2017).

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Mr King, ladies and gentlemen, I am honored to present the report on the fight against cybercrime, as it is called, because I have had the opportunity for many years to practice law in criminal law at home. but also as a politician to deal with this very important subject. The fight against cybercrime is not easy, because it requires high specialization, continuous training and information, legal certainty and coordination. In the report I include the elements that highlight the peculiar form and the special character of the crime on the Internet. This lies in the ease and speed with which the crime is committed, in the anonymity, in the cross-border nature of the crime, in the difficult investigation. Large-scale digital threats are evolving rapidly and we do not have the means and tools to do so, because technology and criminals who use technology are always one step ahead of law enforcement and European law. It is our duty, however, to tackle this phenomenon, because the attacks violate the fundamental rights of European citizens, directly and crucially violate the rule of law and undermine the stability of democratic societies. It is worth noting that statistically there are Member States where the annual crime by 50% is in the form of cybercrime and there is also evidence that in 2016 cybercrime attacks against the European Union's electronic systems increased by 20%. This shows us the increase and the speed with which crime on the Internet is evolving. Our report includes parameters that affect the fight against cybercrime. We have highlighted challenges, legislative gaps, legal gaps and new threats. We submit proposals that include its method coordinated cooperation, with the exchange of information between the Member States but also between the Member States of the European Union and third countries and between the police and judicial authorities. Of course, we propose in a special chapter the need to protect vulnerable groups: young people, minors and children, and we emphasize the legislative initiative for the collection and use of electronic evidence and the framework for the collection of personal data always with respect for fundamental rights. At this point we must welcome the new strategy recently announced by the Commission and Mr King, personally, on Internet security. We want to believe that this report also lays a foundation stone and contributes to this effort to shield Internet security. We emphasize the need to make European cybercrime services more operational, such as, for example, ENISA, which is based in Heraklion, Crete and does a very important job, for financial support with European resources, for staffing with adequate human resources. , because our goal is to be able to approach the traces of criminals on the Internet, to be, if possible, in front of them, given that they are always ahead of technology, and to be close to the citizens who trust digital technologies. Ladies and gentlemen, the report is a start in the fight against cybercrime, but above all it is a bet of the European Union on the protection of the rights of citizens who trust technology and, above all, on the protection of the rights of future generations.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, more and more EU citizens have an e-mail address and electronic communication has become a necessity, but of course it has great risks.The rapporteur, Mrs Vozemberg, spoke about them, and I would like to thank her very much for her report.Recent attacks in the form of ransomware, or ransomware programs, have shown that many people can be affected.Last year alone, more than 4,000 ransom attacks were carried out in the EU over the internet in one day.It is the defense against cybercrime that is an area where cooperation at EU level is desirable and welcomed by citizens, and can better protect not only public institutions, but especially the most vulnerable people in the online environment, such as children and the elderly.I would like to remind you that just this month, on 13 September 2017, the Commission adopted a package of measures to address cybercrime.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in parallel with technological developments, the phenomenon of cybercrime is taking on ever more complex and diversified forms. Cybercrime, in fact, increasingly causes significant social and economic damage affecting the fundamental rights of people, represents a threat to the rule of law in cyberspace and a risk to the stability of democratic societies. To carry out effective law enforcement action, the definition of offenses related to attacks against information systems, as well as the sexual exploitation and sexual abuse of children online, should be harmonized, and Member States should be obliged to establish systems for the registration and exchange of statistical data on these crimes. The fight against cybercrime must be tackled by aiming at strengthening critical infrastructures and networked devices, as well as repressive measures, of course. Given its cross-border nature, close cooperation with third countries is indispensable, including through the exchange of best practices, joint investigations, capacity building and mutual legal assistance.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Vozemberg-Vryonidis, on her report, which really raises important issues that we need to address, because there are really many cases of cyberattacks against countries. both against businesses and against citizens. So measures need to be taken that are really effective. But preventive measures must at the same time respect personal data and, above all, the democratic rights of citizens. The accountability of service providers is very important, as is strengthening cooperation between the police and the judiciary. ENISA should be strengthened. It must remain in Heraklion and this mockery must stop, that is, there must be other services in Heraklion, Crete and others in Athens. ENISA should work hard.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, cybercrime is the new threat, and it is only just beginning. The latest Petya and WannaCry attacks have dramatically demonstrated, firstly, the vulnerability of our systems, secondly, the dazzling spread of these attacks and, third, above all, our critical delay in terms of efficiency and the lead time. 'have cybercriminals in this area. My colleague Elissavet's report - and I welcome its content - responds to a number of priorities, she said. I will take three of them. First of all, resistance and resilience. We must strengthen the protection of infrastructure, networks and content, including encryption. Then the answer. The authorities must be endowed with human and budgetary resources because they are starting to be overwhelmed. Finally, citizens must be made more aware of their behavior. I take this opportunity to salute October, which is European Cyber ​​Security Month. In this respect, it is not a gimmick.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: – Madam President, this report states, right at the beginning, the European Parliament ‘underlines that the fight against cybercrime should be first and foremost about safeguarding and hardening critical infrastructures and other networked devices, and not only about pursuing repressive measures’. That is the central point of this report, and it is why Parliament also stresses the importance of free and open-source software and reiterates that, with respect to the Internet of Things, producers are the key starting-point for tightening up liability regimes which will lead to a better quality of products and a more secure environment in terms of external access and a documented update facility. Parliament also says clearly that it urges the Member States – which are absent here – not to impose any obligation on encryption providers that would result in the weakening or compromising of the security of their networks or services, such as the creation or facilitation of ‘back doors’. I hope, Commissioner, that you will follow these guidelines.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, this 89-paragraph report has got some wonderful aims. We all want to fight against cybercrime, as it becomes proportionately more and more important every single year, and we all want to make sure that the internet is safe for us all to use and enjoy. There are a number of positives that I do see such as – and a colleague has already mentioned this – in terms of open-source software. We are concerned about hacking and about fighting against that. Those borders are not just national; nor are they just European, but they are global. Global cooperation is needed. But one thing does worry me, which is that we must always balance security with freedom of expression and the right to privacy. I see in the report itself precious little that would really remind us of the existence of that balance or that would indeed fully take it into account. As is often said, if a citizen desires privacy, they may have something to hide. Only in the same context, I suppose, as people who have curtains in their houses.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in March 2017, the European Commission adopted its action plan for the development of retail financial services. This action plan recommends the massive use of new digital technologies, fintechs, to develop citizens' access to cross-border financial services. This plan is based in particular on the “eIDAS” regulation, which obliges Member States to do two things: on the one hand, each country must have set up an electronic identity system for its citizens before September 29, 2018, and on the other hand, each country will automatically have to accept the electronic identity systems of other States. The objective for the Commission is thus to allow, for example, that a citizen in Spain, on the basis of his Spanish electronic identity, can have a bank account in Latvia, without having to travel to that country. I want to highlight two important issues: this plan helps reduce the ability of states to protect their own citizens, and in the area of ​​financial services, it increases the risk of massive fraud. Thus, we learned that the electronic identity system in Estonia had recently been hacked. It is for this reason that we will be voting abstention.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, it is practically impossible to fully protect cyberspace against opportunists, criminal networks and terrorists, who can strike a disproportionate blow with relatively limited means. European decisions, on the other hand, complicate the work of surveillance, arrest and prosecution authorities by imposing restrictions on police and judicial access to suspects' data and data retention in the light of the principles of necessity and proportionality. ENISA, Europol and Eurojust can contribute to the principles of identifying and handling digital evidence on how to use social media, best ways to report cyberattacks and understand practical jurisprudential aspects of communications privacy. The required innovative and flexible responses must not further reduce the process for Member States. In the alternative, the Commission should limit itself to enforcing mandatory and reciprocal responses to requests for law enforcement services and to the cooperation and accountability of service providers.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, just as people, services and things become more and more sophisticated and interconnected, so are they becoming more likely to become targets of ever more intense and complex cybercrime. As the 2016 report of The Internet Organised Crime Threat Assessment (IOCTA) revealed, cybercrime even exceeds traditional crime in some EU countries and is closely interlinked with other dangerous areas of crime. A comprehensive European approach to building cybercrime resilience therefore would need to be able to reply to diverse challenges. Besides harmonisation of legislation, it should be recognised that companies cannot deal with the challenge alone, and new regulation should provide more and efficient legal tools and incentives encouraging safer behaviour by service providers and users. Technological development allowed a previously unforeseen level of convenience, ease of use of services and well-being. But these can be safeguarded only in a free, open and secure cyberspace.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this is an important and timely report on how our society deals with new emerging issues of safety and security online. These issues impact our private and public lives, as well as the way we conduct our democratic politics. We must balance the need for safety online with privacy, and we must guarantee freedom of expression and association, while combating incitement to violence and radicalisation. It is also crucial that we protect our democratic institutions and elections from being hijacked, such as during the UK referendum or, recently, in the US elections. We must legislate to prevent data mining companies like Cambridge Analytica using secret money to harvest private data and use it to disseminate disinformation, as reported by the investigative journalist Carole Cadwalladr. These are new challenges, and only a large global actor like the EU can take action to tackle them.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her very comprehensive report, it has many aspects. I would like to address only one aspect, and that is the issue of electoral risks in connection with cyber attacks. I am glad that the EU has also taken up this issue at the ongoing summit or a special conference under the Estonian Presidency. It is important to me that those attacks, which can take on very dramatic proportions in the elections in the individual Member States, that we are actually addressing. They have several contexts for me, of course in the election campaign and then in the counting of votes. The possibility of influencing the election results in connection with cyber attacks is indeed considerable. We therefore need to build a resilient system that is integral and, secondly, to be at the forefront of professional development, that is, to be leaders in the field. It will only save us in terms of the future and in terms of possible cyber attacks.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, cybercrime represents one of the most insidious threats globally today. According to Europol's 2017 IOCTA report, crimes committed via the Internet over the past year have increased, in some cases, by as much as 750%: cyber attacks, cyber fraud and identity theft are on the rise, with unprecedented levels. found previously. To address this challenge, a common European criminal framework is needed first, which prescribes a uniform definition of cybercrime and provides homogeneous guidelines on the identification and trial use of e-evidence. But the fight against cybercrime can only be successful through close collaboration between competent authorities and service providers, a synergy that has already proven to be an effective weapon against cybercrime, and European online risk prevention and management campaigns are needed. , addressed to adults but also to minors, particularly exposed to sexual solicitation or exploitation and cyberbullying.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, I, in turn, would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Vozemberg-Vryonidis, on her comprehensive report on the particularly sensitive and serious issue of cybercrime. As we know, cyber attack is one of the most powerful weapons of hybrid warfare, because it also increases cybercrime, which extends to activities beyond traditional crime, such as sexual exploitation, child pornography and difficulty operating. of digital international commerce. In fact, if terrorist organizations gain access to cyberspace, then the threats that will exist will be very significant. In order to deal with this whole situation, all states must work together, they must enforce a cyber justice system, the judicial and police authorities must work together and the vulnerability of all these points must be identified. . Finally, I also emphasize the need for the integrated operation of ENISA and we must definitely be careful, when implementing these measures, not to violate human rights.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! A study by the Bertelsmann Foundation shows that 80% of schoolchildren in Germany would like to use digital media in school lessons. Even if we are still a long way from widespread use, the question arises: Do young people sufficiently learn how to use digital services and their personal data responsibly? This report on the fight against cybercrime shows that all citizens should know how to protect themselves against cybercrime. Almost everyone uses digital services, has a smartphone or laptop. Thus, almost everyone is a potential victim of cyber criminals. We must therefore improve global police and judicial cooperation, and it is imperative that we invest in more education. I therefore reiterate the call on the European Commission to launch a user awareness campaign. But the topic of digitization and its dangers should also be given more space in schools. This is the only way we can be sure that the younger generation will also be better protected against cyber attacks.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is a key subject and I am glad it has been raised. I want to thank the rapporteur for her personal contribution, and indeed all the Members for their engagement on this subject. As has been noted, cyber-attacks do not pay heed to geographical borders. They can be achieved at a surprisingly low cost, but with devastating effect, and they pose a risk to our security and sometimes to our democratic processes and institutions. Which is why we need to promote our cybersecurity, and that indeed was the objective of the package of measures the Commission issued on 19 September. As a number of you have suggested, we need to build on what already exists so we recognise the importance of the European Union Agency for Network Information and Security (ENISA) and of Europol, but we need to strengthen the work that they have been doing and strengthen cooperation between the various agencies and instruments. We have the Directive on the Security of Network and Information Systems. Once that is fully implemented it will improve national cybersecurity capabilities, enhance cooperation between Member States and require operators in important economic sectors such as energy, transport, banking and health, as well as digital service providers, to adopt risk-management measures, and report major incidents to national authorities. However, some of the attacks that we have seen recently, like the ‘WannaCry’ attack and the ‘Not Petya’ attack, showed the need to do even more on resilience and on preparedness. Resilience means being harder to attack and quicker to respond, so a proposed cybersecurity act would revise the mandate of ENISA and reinforce it. We are also proposing to introduce an EU certification framework for internet-connected products and services. Building on the cybersecurity public-private partnership, the Commission has said that we want to create a network of cybersecurity competence centres and a new European cybersecurity research and competence centre at its hub. Both network and centre would contribute to increased investment and reinforce capabilities across the European Union. Cybercrime should not pay. Sadly, it will continue and will continue to grow as long as it does appear to pay, so we also need to take steps – as well as building our resilience – to improve deterrents and to make cybercrime easier to detect, trace and prosecute. We want law enforcement agencies to have the tools they need to tackle online crime effectively. The Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on non-cash payment fraud, a crime that is worth some EUR 1.5 billion in the eurozone alone. We take a technologically neutral approach, but we want to facilitate cross-border cooperation and ensure that this crime is treated as seriously as it deserves to be. We have said that, by the beginning of 2018, we will propose measures to improve cross-border access to electronic evidence for criminal investigations. With regard to encryption – mentioned by a number of you – when it comes to encryption in criminal investigations, we are reviewing possible options and possible ways forward, and we will revert both to the Council and to this House. But we recognise, and we agree, that strong encryption is key to how we use the internet. It has a key role in maintaining effective cybersecurity. We recognise and respect that. Finally, we agree with Parliament’s calls for action to empower and protect children from online risks. The annual Safer Internet Day is a flagship event promoting awareness amongst children, teachers and parents. Next year’s Safer Internet Day is on 6 February. The Commission is considering launching a major EU-wide campaign covering online safety and cybersecurity for minors. Our communication last week on tackling illegal content online also set out guidelines to encourage more effective identification and removal of illegal content, including material in relation to child sexual abuse. It explicitly encourages more proactive measures to tackle this scourge. I want to thank you again for your engagement on these issues. From the Commission side we very much looking forward to continuing our discussion and dialogue with you on building our cybersecurity.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 3 October 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The fight against cybercrime, a rapidly growing phenomenon, is both difficult and delicate.Indeed, it is difficult to combat a problem at national level which, by its nature, does not have any type of barrier, hence the fundamental importance of a coordinated approach at European level;then the relationship between the need to face the matter and that of safeguarding the right to the protection of personal data, privacy and freedom of expression is delicate.Finding a balance between these two aspects is not easy but, as mentioned, it is absolutely necessary and urgent.The presented report succeeds in this difficult task and I am therefore happy to support it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – It is a well—established fact that citizens’ everyday lives are becoming increasingly digital. Our energy supply, our homes, our banking systems and even our hospitals are all today very much reliant on technology. And with great technology, comes great responsibility; a responsibility to ensure that citizens’ data is safe, critical infrastructure is not rendered inoperable, democracies and voting systems are not compromised, and that ultimately citizens lives aren’t put into jeopardy because of cyber-attacks, such as the ransomware attack which crippled the NHS just a short few months ago. Let me be clear though, the technological advances which have made such attacks possible are not only challenges, but they are also opportunities. We must recognise that such progress has resulted in ample young talent youth who are ready to contribute to a greater good. This is why we are calling on the industry and governments to engage with white hat hackers – those who do what they do out of morality and not for monetary purposes. The EU cannot fight the fight against cybercrime alone – we must use our best resource; our youth.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Digitization and the spread of the internet are changing our lives at a rapid pace. New tools and new relationships open up new horizons for us and cause previously unimaginable efficiencies. We spend more and more time on the internet as new connected devices keep appearing in our lives. They make our lives faster and more comfortable, but at the same time we must not forget that such a rapid transformation also carries dangers. The anonymity and encryption that comes with the internet provide great coverage. In the conflicts of recent years, in addition to armed clashes, war has also erupted in cyberspace. By now, cyber warfare has reached the same level as traditional weapons and every major country has its own hacker squad. However, cyber-attacks are not limited to conflicts between states, but many independent and unknown organizations are trying to exploit the opportunities offered by the World Wide Web, as evidenced by data theft and extortion viruses in recent years. In such an uncertain and threatening environment, our priority is to protect the security of European citizens. The protection of services, infrastructure, property and personal data is just as important as physical security. I believe that the issue of cybersecurity is one of the most pressing problems of our time and that rapid and effective cooperation is needed.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Reinhard Bütikofer, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU's political relations with ASEAN (2017/2026 (INI)) (A8-0243 / 2017).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Since this House adopted its first report on political relations between the EU and the ASEAN group of states in 2014, a great deal of positive has happened in this area. The second report that the AFET committee is now presenting to the plenary session reflects this. At the same time, we have the opportunity to look back on 50 years of ASEAN and 40 years of relations between the EU and ASEAN and to take this as an opportunity to describe a new phase in these relations. For us, the ASEAN community is a strategic partner that is important for cooperation throughout the Indo-Pacific region. It is particularly important that this is a partner who, like the EU, advocates multilateralism and the international rule of law. The collaboration now extends to more areas than ever before. In the area of ​​connectivity, for example, we are negotiating an air transport agreement. There is cooperation on the environment or on the UN's sustainability goals or the question of natural resources. There is cooperation on security at sea, piracy, cooperation between Europol and Aseanapol against organized crime, against terrorism, with regard to cybersecurity and, of course, crisis management. The issues of promoting democracy and promoting human rights also continued to play a major role in our relationships. In the report, we address the obligation of entrepreneurs who invest there within the very close trade and investment relationship between the EU and ASEAN, the obligation with regard to social and environmental responsibility. We address the possibilities of cooperation at the municipal level, the possibilities of cooperation between people - especially among the younger generation - and one of the specific projects, this one what is proposed is that a Young Leaders Program be set up between the EU and ASEAN.Finally, the report also emphasizes that we want to promote cooperation between parliamentarians on both sides.Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it has been a very fruitful, very constructive collaboration with the shadow rapporteurs from the various political groups.There is a great deal of agreement.At one point we even managed to formulate a self-criticism with regard to the EU's not particularly laudable hesitation when it came to giving an opinion on the decision of the Unclos Court on the South China Sea.But the bottom line is that it is a positive development that we are giving our support with a lot of commitment and that we hope will gain even more momentum in the next few years.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Ms. President! Like the rapporteur, I myself strongly support the resumption of negotiations and negotiations on an EU-ASEAN Free Trade Agreement. As the EU's third largest trading partner outside Europe, ASEAN can make a significant contribution to adapting more quickly and effectively to changes in world trade patterns. At the same time, it is important that enhanced cooperation between the states of the region can also improve the chances of addressing the significant economic and social disparities between ASEAN Member States. It is therefore in the common interest to raise economic and, at the same time, political relations to a higher level, which can of course be accompanied by an improvement in the human rights situation. In this case, too, the proposition that the EU can best contribute to the changes taking place in these societies by setting an example that is attractive to many is valid.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, my congratulations to the rapporteur for his report on EU-ASEAN relations. I had the honour to represent this House at the ASEAN interparliamentary assembly in Manila, a fortnight back. I very much concur with what Mr Bütikofer has said in relation to having dialogue with young people and with the ASEAN parliamentarians. It is so important that we actually have dialogue with the ASEAN parliamentarians, as opposed to just having individual bilateral relationships with Member States of ASEAN. I raised the issues that this Parliament has raised, condemning the atrocities committed in Myanmar against the Rohingya minority. I was the only one, apart from the Indonesian Head of Delegation, to do so. Afterwards, delegates from many other countries came up and said they really did support this and that we had to do more to work together to stop these atrocities. Through you, madam President, I would like to extend an invitation to the ASEAN parliamentarians if we can.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I offer my congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Bütikofer, and I thank him for the excellent cooperation on this report. Deepening cooperation with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is in our mutual strategic, political and economic interest. Not only has ASEAN become one of the fastest growing regions in the world, the integration of ASEAN countries is increasingly important in terms of security and stability. We should use relations with ASEAN to step up our economic and political presence in this strategically important region.  The EU is one of the biggest investors in and trading partners of ASEAN. We need to be ambitious and build on this cooperation. Taking steps forward to the strategic partnership would certainly strengthen our economic trade, political and security relations. To this end, it is important to intensify political dialog with ASEAN countries. This is one of the most important messages of this resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the European Union's relations with ASEAN are indeed particularly important. They cover a wide range of sectors: trade, investment, development, economics and politics. ASEAN is the third largest trading partner of the European Union, the European Union is the second largest trading partner of ASEAN, the annual bilateral trade exceeds 200 billion euros, while the European Union is the first force in foreign direct investment in the region. This is because there the European multinationals have found a paradise, they have found places where they can produce their own products instead of a low-wage lentil board. Unfortunately, they are not interested in the observance of labor rights, nor in the observance of environmental conditions, nor in the safety of workers. I think these are mentioned in point 14 of the report. The European Union must not neglect, in the name of so-called development, the protection of labor and human rights.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, I am glad that there is an ASEAN-type organization in South-East Asia.I am convinced that a lot of cooperation and mutual assistance is needed in this area.Winter is approaching, during which there were massive fires in Indonesia at the end of 2015.For about 8,000 kilometers, a rainforest burned on more than two million hectares.The fire in three weeks released more CO2 into the atmosphere than Germany can handle in a whole year.Irresponsible palm oil production was to blame.The 69 million people of Indonesia and Borneo were breathing polluted air, and thousands of people paid with their lives for these fires.I would therefore like to take this opportunity to appeal to both the ASEAN and the EU countries to help Indonesia prevent any fires this year.We have only one planet and we have a shared responsibility for it, and we must never forget that.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
