text: - Madam President! In the 40th EU-ASEAN anniversary year, we are calling for EU-ASEAN relations to be upgraded to a strategic partnership. Partnership and cooperation agreements have been and are being negotiated with seven countries, the Philippines are likely to benefit from the GSP + trading system, and free trade agreements have been negotiated with Singapore and Vietnam. In contrast, the human rights situation in several ASEAN countries has unfortunately deteriorated dramatically recently, for example the ethnic displacement and excesses of violence against the Rohingya in Myanmar, the attacks on the opposition and civil society in the run-up to the elections in Cambodia, the massive increase in extrajudicial executions the philippines. The EU must use its trade relations more decisively and effectively to improve human rights protection. In doing so, it must proceed in a credible and consistent manner, i.e. also apply the human rights clauses and suspend trade advantages if necessary.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for an excellent report.I think he has done a huge amount of work, and I would also like to thank everyone who contributed to this report, because it seems very balanced to me.It has already been mentioned here that ASEAN is the third most important trading partner for us, but no one has mentioned here that we are the second most important trading partner for ASEAN and the dialogue and development of trade relations need to be further deepened.What I would say to the Commissioner, and what he should take away from this dialogue with the Commission, is that we also want to develop that very political dialogue, we want to raise human rights issues.Unfortunately, in many ASEAN countries, the issues of human rights and the rule of law are simply empty.In addition, there is a need to talk to states about the environment, about greater security and, perhaps, about the topic of innovation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to emphasize that, indeed, the reciprocal trade relationship of that exchange makes this space very important for both parties.This was emphasized by the rapporteur, who said that the Indo-Pacific area was indeed a strategic one for the EU, and I think that the EU's opportunity is multiplied by the Trump administration clearing that area.This is a huge opportunity for the EU, I think Mr Trump's policy is undoubtedly wrong, and we should strengthen our diplomatic capacity to take advantage of this weakness, because it is an opportunity, I repeat, for the EU.In this context, I would like to remind you that at the last plenary session, we also talked about India, which is also a strategic country for Europe, without a late-night debate.I think that the role and importance of these sites, these countries, would really be emphasized if we talked in a proper debate, not in this way.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome this report on behalf of the Commission and High Representative/Vice—President Mogherini. It speaks to the importance the EU attributes to relations with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), notwithstanding the last comment. It is also an appropriate way to celebrate this 40th anniversary.  Europe and the ASEAN region may be separated geographically, but we remain closely linked. What happens in Southeast Asia matters to us, and – I think we all agree – the same is true for our ASEAN friends. Today’s challenges and crises very often have a global dimension, a global impact. The situation in the South China Sea and in the Korean peninsula, the fight against terrorism, radicalisation to mention just a few examples are ASEAN interests, but they are our interests too.  The EU wants to contribute to the security of the ASEAN region. The EU has become one of the main contributors to the security-related activities of the ASEAN Regional Forum. In 2017, we have sponsored initiatives on counter-radicalisation, people trafficking, preventive diplomacy and mediation. For the third year in a row, we have invited ASEAN partners to be acquainted with the EU’s capabilities in common defence and security policies. A seminar in Rome allowed for a visit to the headquarters of Operation Sophia. Shortly, the EU will co-sponsor the fourth edition of the EU-ASEAN high-level dialogue on maritime security this year with the Philippines. We see the recent invitation to attend the November East Asia Summit as an acknowledgment of these efforts. We want to thank all ASEAN members, and in particular the Philippines, for inviting us. We look forward to contributing to the summit’s work as a partner and a friend. The same goes for other security and defence forums in Southeast Asia, notably the ASEAN Defence Ministers’ Meeting Plus.  There is much we can do together in terms of trade, connectivity, making the most out of globalisation, as well as addressing together the imbalances it can give rise to. Both the EU and ASEAN want to continue fighting climate change and to preserve the Paris Agreement. I am glad that we adopted, in August, a joint statement to reaffirm that we stand by Paris, and we will push forward implementation.  We should not underestimate the joint potential of cooperation between EU and ASEAN in a range of sectors. After all, as has been noted, together we represent over one billion people, and we are among the largest world economies.  The European Union is the first foreign investor in ASEAN and the second trading partner. The impact of bilateral free trade agreements between the European Union and Singapore, Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand would be huge, with great benefits for our companies and citizens. These agreements could be the stepping stones towards a future region-to-region agreement.  The comprehensive air transport agreement we are negotiating would be the first of its kind. Once finalised, thousands of new jobs will be created, and one billion people will be able to fly directly for lower prices and with the highest standards of security.  The potential for greater engagement is huge. To turn this potential into reality, in Manila in August the EU and ASEAN adopted a comprehensive plan of action to guide cooperation from 2018 to 2022. All the key areas of common interest are covered, including human rights, good governance, women’s rights and the rule of law.  Forty years ago, we took the first steps to build cooperation between the European Union and ASEAN. We have come a long way since. Today, every day, we see that many of our interests coincide, as do many of the challenges we face. The EU remains committed to comprehensively upgrading the EU-ASEAN relationship. We can be proud of what we have achieved over the last 40 years. We should be ambitious about what we can do together in the years ahead.  Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your engagement on this report and the debate this evening.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 3 October 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - ASEAN recently celebrated its 50th anniversary. The population is similar to the EU, it should be noted that it has some problems, if not the same. Forty years since the first EU-ASEAN relations were established, we have seen positive developments in cooperation in a number of areas. However, as in the EU, some countries face human rights and non-citizen violations. Large stateless communities are currently located in Brunei, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia and especially Myanmar. It concerns Rohingya, whose position is worse in ASEAN countries than in the case of stateless citizens in EU countries. Unfortunately, the report does not mention them. It should be noted that tens of thousands of non-citizens have long lived in EU countries, specifically Latvia and Estonia. These non-citizens even have personal documents, such as a passport, marked non-citizens. One of the big problems of ASEAN countries is the protection of the environment and the fight against piracy. The South China Sea has long failed to resolve the conflict between the ASEAN countries and between the ASEAN countries and China. However, the EU is not free of similar problems either. International arbitration between Slovenia and Croatia in the Piran Bay is a similar small conflict. Both sides, the EU and ASEAN, should be called upon to address the issues outlined.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written.- Promoting partnerships with members of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a strategic advantage for the EU.Together, ASEAN is the world's seventh largest economy and ASEAN is the EU's third largest trading partner.The value of annual bilateral trade in goods is over € 200 billion.The region is one of the most dynamic and fastest growing in the world in terms of technology and research as well.Dialogue and cooperation are of common interest in many areas, from cyber security to combating climate change.The strategic partnership must not, of course, be pursued without turning a blind eye to human rights violations in the region, for example.The partnerships should also promote the UN Recommendations on Business and Human Rights.The EU has the opportunity to use its relations to influence the realization of human rights in the region, both through its trade partnerships and through development aid.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute remarks on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Ms. President! In the Slovak Republic, of which I am a citizen, citizens belonging to the Hungarian national minority again complain that they are harassed by Slovak language police officers because they use their mother tongue in accordance with the applicable laws. Yes, you hear me, I am not talking about Orwell's animal farm, but about reality: in Slovakia, an EU Member State, there is a language police force where any citizen can report to another because they used their minority language somewhere and can be fined thousands of euros. When they come to Slovakia, they see that companies are advertising only English or other foreign language advertisements on huge surfaces. This is contrary to the chauvinist language law in force, but it is tolerated by all. However, it is no longer the case that the country’s own citizens who belong to a minority use their mother tongue, for example on public subtitles. I would like to ask Mr Timmermans and Mrs Jourová to ask the Slovak Government for information on this.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Madam President, on Sunday, September 10, a relatively small tanker sank in the Saronic Gulf of Greece. According to experts, the oil spill was not significant at first and could have been reduced before it spread. However, as everyone can see from the pictures, huge environmental damage was caused and professional fishermen were driven to despair. There has already been strong criticism of the reaction and the oligarchy of the state apparatus. In any case, we can now ask some important questions: do the national authorities, which judge the navigability of such ships, have the technical training and the independence of a recognized classification society? Secondly, should this ship, which was 45 years old, please sail in European waters? For us Greeks, Madam President, you know, the sea is, historically, of special importance and determines us socially, economically and culturally. With the assistance of the European Union, I hope that we will make the protection of the sea our main goal.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, these days the National Assembly of the Republic of Albania is considering an extremely important law, which is also being passed under pressure from the European Parliament, namely the law on national minorities. It lists several such communities, but lacks a historical community that has been recognized by the Albanian state since 1932, and that is the Bulgarian community. This, of course, aroused our surprise, because, as is well known, in this room in last year's report on Albania's progress towards the European Union, the European Parliament explicitly mentioned the Bulgarian community among those in Albania and insisted on the Albanian government and parliament to take all necessary measures to preserve the rights and legitimate interests of these citizens of the Republic of Bulgaria - Bulgarians by origin. That is why my appeal to the Government of the Republic of Albania is to respect European rules and norms and not to turn this extremely important bilateral issue into a field of speculation that only pleases Belgrade and other countries and harms our good friendly relations.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, I want to show my solidarity with all those injured yesterday in Catalonia during a disproportionate and violent police action. It only served to violate fundamental rights and alter coexistence, against express court orders to the contrary. I hope it is the last chapter of a wrong strategy: denying reality and trying to repress by means of sentences a political problem to whose solution the European Union should contribute as an agent of coexistence. Spain proclaims itself a united nation but is, in reality, a union of nations. The majority of the citizens of Catalonia and the Basque Country want this reality to be recognized and assumed on the basis of mutual respect, dialogue, negotiation, agreement and ratification: a legal and agreed referendum. I regret that the most powerful part, which also violates laws, does not trust what it offers to join with Basques and Catalans. Violence, abuse of power, verbal escalations or electoral use of these conflicts at the cost of festering them are not a seductive project. They generate bankruptcies of coexistence that no responsible politician should allow or encourage.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr. President: kicks to the head, blows, rubber balls, broken fingers and even a complaint for sexual assault.Remember that these people just wanted to vote.Given this, the silence of the European institutions.A complicit silence.After this, who guarantees that the strike that is called for Tuesday will not repeat this police brutality?On Sunday, millions of Catalans gave a lesson, they responded to the repression with democracy.It can be argued if we want, like the Popular Party and the Socialist Party, for Catalonia to stay under the Spanish monarchy or if we throw out "the Bourbon" and build a federal republic together or if we bet on independence, but it is the Catalans and theCatalan women who decide on their future.Against the violent imposition of the right of self-determination of the peoples.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to express solidarity here today with Jacques Sapir, one of the heterodox French economists who, unfortunately, was silenced a few days ago.In fact, the platform where he has been publishing his analyzes of him for the past eight years, has decided not to allow him to publish these analyzes anymore because they go against the French government.As it happens, Mr. Dacos, who is the manager of this platform, has been appointed as a consultant to the Macron government.Solidarity with Jacques Sapir, one of the few free and critical voices against this European Union and against Europe: if this is democracy, if this is the freedom of expression that he who is presented as the reformer and savior of Europe wants, Macron, we're not there.We protect the freedom of speech and expression of those who have denounced the horrors of this European Union.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President!Ukraine has repeatedly violated the principles it has undertaken to enforce in the Association Agreement with the EU.Most recently, despite international protests, it passed an education law that makes it impossible for national minorities to be educated in their mother tongue, including the 150,000-native Hungarian community.Last week, the Ukrainian authorities did not allow Krisztina Morvai, a Member of the European Parliament, to enter the country, the alleged reason for the ban, which she did not know before, is based on the accusation that she visited Donbass in 2014 and supported the separatists.This statement is a lie.The Member has never been to Donbass.This is a serious provocation that has hit the European Parliament itself through him, so it cannot be left without consequences.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, let me draw attention to the situation in Turkey. I visited this country ten days ago, despite the fact that the official EP delegations to Turkey were canceled, with which I categorically disagree. I wanted to see the integration of more than three million refugees in Turkey. I was very positively surprised by the efforts, the successful results of those who care for refugees in Turkey on the ground, from civil servants, schools to employers. EU funds are also used very well here for the benefit of those who need them. Unfortunately, all this in contrast to the fact that I must say that the political situation in Turkey is not good. I had the opportunity to speak with family members of imprisoned journalists, representatives of persecuted academics and supporters of imprisoned Buyukada activists. From here, I want to support their fight for democracy and Turkey's return to the values ​​of the rule of law, civil and human rights. Today, October 2, when World Nonviolence Day is a memorial to Mahatma Gandhi's birthday. Let us support Turkish citizens and friends in their ... (the President cut off the floor).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Madam President, as your honorable Members know, Spain is the main table olive exporter in the world, to which Andalusia contributes 80%, from Seville, Jaén or Córdoba, and a turnover of more than 350 million euros per year.They know that the American food industry has filed complaints about low-price antidumping procedures - low price assumption - for CAP aid, before the World Trade Organization, which the European Commission knows is not true.It is not true, because he knows that the CAP is perfectly aligned with the rules of the World Trade Organization.That is why I ask the Commission to establish a dialogue with the US Administration, as well as to make an explicit statement and adopt concrete measures that provide the legal certainty that the table olive agri-food sector needs at this time, so important in my life.region and the whole of Spain.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! For Europe we agree: violence is no solution! At the same time, as a member of the AKP delegation, I would like to direct our focus on an escalation of violence that has been happening 4,000 kilometers from here since Sunday and which must have been very close to us historically. In Cameroon there has been excessive violence by the French-speaking government since Sunday against people who wanted to celebrate the 56th birthday of their English-speaking region. Since then there has been a message blackout and the Internet has been switched off. Amnesty says it is an "ongoing campaign to silence any form of dissent in the West and South-West regions of Cameroon". The colonial powers France and Great Britain have a special responsibility here. You have created the mess that has already taken many victims. Let's not be silent! Structures created must be ordered and pacified. Let's stand on the side of Africa - not because of the power over raw materials, but for the sake of the people who have a right to finally be African.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, the PKK is on the European Union's list of terrorist organizations. That is respectable. However, there is a recent decision of the Belgian Court of Appeals, which ruled that the PKK is not a terrorist organization. I personally say clearly that I am not in a position to say what the character of this organization really is and I am against any terrorism, as any serious person should be. However, I think that a review of this position of the European Union can lead, at the urging of the European Union, to negotiations between the Turkish state and the PKK, in order to find a way out of the problem that plagues the country.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a referendum on autonomy will be held in Lombardy and Veneto on 22 October. I think it would be right and also appropriate to greet the European Parliament on this day of freedom and democracy, based on the sacrosanct principle of self-determination of peoples, which my movement, the Northern League for the independence of Padania, has always supported. on these benches. On Sunday I voluntarily played the role of international observer as a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the European Parliament in Catalonia and, authorized by the Generalitat, I attended the polling stations and I wanted to testify on these benches the regularity of this vote, the peaceful and absolutely non-partisan, non-violent, non-partisan of this request supported by a very large part of the Catalan people. I want to pay tribute to this people and their determination and naturally condemn the acts of violence. I truly hope that there is a lot of solidarity in Europe and that the silence of the European authorities is deplorable.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, today I have to comment on the frightening images we saw from Catalonia on Sunday. The pictures are so shocking that everyone has to say to themselves: Are they pictures from an EU member state? Using rubber projectiles against peaceful voters, who hold maximum ballot papers in their hands, is a scene that I would expect at most somewhere in Russia, not in an EU democratic state. We can definitely not be silent, I will not in any case. Here in the European Parliament, I am a member of the European People's Party, in which my colleagues from Spain are also members, elected as Mr Rajoy's party. I am aware that the issue is an internal matter of a Member State, of course it is a question of Spanish constitutional law. However, the number of injured is forcing us all in the European People's Party to condemn this ruthless intervention. Today, I want to condemn him with all determination and I want to hold the Spanish Government to account.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, thank you for allowing me to address this House on the protection of consumers within the digital single market. The Commission is currently consulting on this area, and I very much hope that one of the outcomes will be the strengthening of those aspects of the Consumer Rights Directive on complete price information. This directive seems to have been broadly effective in ensuring that consumers can make purchasing decisions with full information and without hidden charges.  There are still, however, many areas where digital trading pushes the boundaries of good practice. For example, in sports and music ticketing – where demand is especially price-inelastic – leading aftermarket sites frequently add outrageous service and delivery charges well after the point where the buyer is emotionally committed to the purchase. Meanwhile, the technology applies pressure to buyers who are prepared to pay whatever it takes to see their favourite performer, band or football match. I hope we will see the Commission addressing this issue in the near future.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President!As part of my one-minute speeches, I would like to protest against the announced amendment to the European Commission directive forcing fathers to take four-month paternity leave without the possibility of transferring it to the other parent.After giving birth, mothers may be forced to return to work faster, which will not only weaken the necessary bond between the mother and the child, but also cause irreversible psychophysical effects.According to psychologists, a child tolerates separation well from its mother only for as many hours as it is old.The absence of a mother for eight hours in the first year of life will cause separation anxiety, physical disorders, diseases and identity disorders, especially since from the sixth month of life the mother's attachment and influence on the child increases, and the unconscious child identifies with the mother until the age of two.The father, on the other hand, plays an important role later on.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá mé ag iarraidh labhairt anocht ar ábhar cearta daonna, daonlathas agus saoirse tionóil. Is léir ón méid a bhí le feiceáil inné gur léiriú cumhachtach, daonlathach, síochánta a bhí sa reifreann sa Chatalóin. Tá dualgas orainn mar fheisirí i bparlaimint daonlathach seasamh anois le muintir na Catalóine. Ní féidir linn neamhaird a dhéanamh ar na radhairc dhrámatúla agus scanrúla a bhí le feiceáil ar shráideanna agus i scoileanna na Catalóine inné. Agus ní féidir leis an Aontas Eorpach neamhaird a dhéanamh ar an teachtaireacht láidir a tháinig ó mhuintir na tíre sin. Ní féidir linn ach a bheith buartha agus feargach agus póilíní na Spáinne ag déanamh ionsaí ar ionaid vótála, ionsaí ar shaoránaigh agus iad ag vótáil, agus ag scaoileadh urchair phlaisteacha leis na sluaite. An é seo an próiseas daonlathach atá uainn - ag greadadh daoine agus iad ag caitheamh vóta? Mo náire iad.  Tá dualgas orainn mar dhaonlathaithe foréigean agus brú faoi chois na Spáinne a cháineadh. Cuireann ciúnas ár gceannairí náire orm, agus tá sé thar bheith in am dóibh siúd a nguth a ardú anois. Caithfidh an tAontas Eorpach seasamh go hiomlán le muintir na Catalóine ar son na saoirse agus ar son an daonlathais.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I am very pleased that you are sitting here today, because I would like to draw attention to one issue that has not been much talked about here in the European Parliament. These are the results of Operation OPSON, which took place under the auspices of Europol and Interpol, during which 10,000 tonnes, 27 million liters and 13 million pieces of potentially harmful food were seized in 61 countries. Commissioner, this is a relatively serious problem. We are dealing with food crime here, and if we do not set up an office to coordinate the action against food crime, the lives of EU citizens could be jeopardized very soon. We have examples here where salt is poured into food, which is used for road maintenance. We have examples here where meat is smuggled. I think something needs to be done about this, and I think there is ... at Europol or the EEAS, for example (the President took the floor).

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to a scandalous situation in my country, Latvia.The illegal waste trade has become a national tragedy.There are many places where unscrupulous private landlords pile up bulky and sometimes toxic waste directly from Switzerland, the Netherlands, etc.This is a very juicy business which harms our environment but unfortunately our national legislation does not allow to stop it and to sanction those responsible.Dear colleagues, we absolutely must put an end to this trafficking through appropriate European legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the problem with red loans is intensifying in Greece, as the SYRIZA-ANEL government launches electronic auctions. The Greek people, although they paid dearly with three memoranda for the successive recapitalizations of the Greek banks, are now under attack by the banks, which have been completely de-Hellenized and which are literally preparing to sell out the "red" loans to the funds, ie the "crows". »Instead of a lentil plate. But the Greek people are not going to allow the troika and the "crows" to snatch their houses. Our party "GREECE - THE OTHER ROAD" demands the establishment of a public fund for "red" loans, a fund to save borrowers, in order to be able to save their homes. The fund could be financed with 4.5 billion euros out of the 25 billion euros left over from the third loan package. In addition, we demand that the model of Cyprus be institutionalized in Greece, so that the borrower has the right to prefer to buy his loan at the price of the first offer made by the "crows".

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: - Madam President, duck farming in the southwest of France is not only a tourist argument, it is also a structuring reality of the regional economy and the territorial network. Yet today 30,000 direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs are at risk. Since 2015 and the start of the bird flu epidemics, things have only gotten worse. In 2017, four million animals were slaughtered preventively, i.e. months of crawl space for more than 1,000 municipalities, and a year without any income for some producers. A slow agony! The compensations awarded are not up to par and anger is growing, feeding on the unfairness of the situation. Indeed, where the losses of large groups have been well compensated, small farms pay a high price. I am a supporter of the precautionary principle and aware of the new standards and controls to be put in place, but this means helping producers to apply these changes and to secure their farms against avian flu, when they have to deal with the combined pressure of delayed CAP payments, new standards, containment measures and costs related to analyzes. What I am asking you today is first of all to become aware of our responsibility in preserving our heritage, to make a clear commitment and to ensure lasting solutions… (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, this evening in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development there were votes on a mandate for trade with New Zealand and Australia, putting forward the concerns of the Agriculture Committee. While we do want Europe to conclude trade agreements, we want it to be sensitive to the impact they can have on farmers in the European Union. In that context there is deep concern, certainly among beef farmers in Ireland, about the potential offer that the European Union will make to the Mercosur countries, and the figure being quoted is of 70 000 tons of tariff-rate quota for beef. This will have consequences not just for Ireland but for livestock farmers across Europe. What I would say to our Trade Commissioner, and indeed to all of the Commissioners, is that they must look very carefully and calculate the combined impact of all these trade agreements on the agriculture sector. We have a common agricultural policy, we have a model of agriculture, and we need to defend it.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Madam President, recently, the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, stated in his State of the Union address the need for Romania and Bulgaria to be accepted in the Schengen area. Subsequently, his message was reinforced by the European Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship, who stated that a coordinated and unitary Schengen area should include Bulgaria and Romania. The European Commission has known and recognized for a long time the fact that Romania has respected its commitments and, therefore, the acceptance of our country in the Schengen area is legitimate, correct and desirable. Such a step is not only to the advantage of Romania or Bulgaria, but to the benefit of the other Member States, because it would allow a strengthening of cooperation for everything that means strengthening security at EU borders. Invoking any pretexts to block Romania's accession to the Schengen area is contrary to the principles we share and counterproductive for the security and economy of the European Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my statement tonight is on people with physical, mental and intellectual disabilities. Yes, we all know that they have rights under the UN Convention. Unfortunately, national laws reflect the rights of these people differently and not only reflect them differently, but also how they are applied. I had several meetings with European associations of people with disabilities, national associations and associations in my country. The discussions I have had have led me to declare this evening, Commissioner, because I believe it is necessary, especially with regard to the guardianship institution, that those persons with disabilities who are under the guardianship of certain persons are purely and simply worse than in detention. So, I think we need to review, to see at national level, at European level, how we could uniformly regulate the rights of tens of millions of people with disabilities. The existence of a disability does not justify the loss of rights and I think it is worth doing this analysis and I ask you to do so, Commissioner.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Ukrainian Parliament has recently adopted an update on the education law enacted by the President of the country. It limits education in the languages ​​of national minorities. This is a brutal violation of the international obligations of the Ukrainian state. Minorities such as the Romanian one and many others will suffer enormously as a result of this law. I am extremely disappointed that the European Union's reactions to this abuse have been non-existent. Today, however, I want to ask the European Parliament to urgently and unreservedly sanction Ukraine. If this country, as it claims, wants to get closer to the European Union, it must know that such laws, motivated by the need to homogenize the population, belong to other centuries. They have nothing to look for in Europe, they cannot be promoted by true friends of the European Union. All these aggressive actions against multiculturalism can be found in the recent speeches of British Brexit negotiators. They threaten, among other things, the possible imposition of visas in the case of Romanians, Bulgarians and Poles. I believe that we have an obligation not to leave all these European citizens alone in the face of abuse and these historical disasters.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: This item on the agenda is thus closed.
